132.03 BUILDING STANDARDS FUND.
   (a)   There is hereby established an agency fund to be known as the
"Building Standards Fund", Fund Number 701 under the provisions of Ohio R.C.
3781.102. The necessity for establishing the Building Standards Fund is to
account for the three percent (3%) fee collected by the City Building
Department for the Board of Building Standards for the State of Ohio.
   (b)   The City shall remit monthly to the Treasurer of the State of Ohio all
moneys collected on behalf of the Board of Building Standards according to Ohio
R.C. 3781.102.
(Ord. 10-74-93. Passed 10-19-93.)
132.04 BUILDING ADVISORY BOARD.
   (a)   Establishment. There is hereby established in accordance with the
powers granted pursuant to Ohio R.C. 715.26, a Building Advisory Board which
shall be comprised of six members consisting of a plumber, electrician, general
contractor, heating and cooling contractor, real estate agent, and home owner,
who shall serve without compensation for terms of three years each. The members
of this Board shall be appointed by the Mayor unless the City has a contract
with the Pickaway County Commissioners to perform building inspection services
within various areas outside the City, in which case, one of the members of
this Board shall be appointed by the County Commissioners. The terms of these
Board members shall be staggered so that two members are appointed annually.
   (b)   Removal of Members. Members of the Board shall be removable by the
Mayor for nonperformance of duty, misconduct in office, or other cause after
the member has been given the opportunity to be heard and to answer such
charges.
   (c)   Organization and Rules.
      (1)   Four members of the Board shall constitute a quorum.
      (2)   The meetings of the Board shall be public; however, the Board may
go into executive session, as permitted by Ohio R.C. 121.22 as amended, for
discussion, but not for vote, on any issue before it.
      (3)   The Board shall organize annually and elect a chairman, clerk, and
other officers as it deems necessary.
      (4)   The Board shall adopt, from time to time, such rules, policies,
procedures and regulations as it may deem necessary to carry into effect the
provisions of this section.
      (5)   The Clerk of the Board shall keep minutes of its proceedings
showing the vote of each member upon each question; or, if absent or failing to
vote, indicating such fact; and shall keep records of its examination and other
official action, all of which shall be immediately filed in the City offices
and shall be of public record.
      (6)   The Board shall have the power to subpoena witnesses, administer
oaths, and may require the production of documents, under such regulations as
it may establish.
      (7)   The Board may call upon the various departments of the City for
assistance in the performance of its duties and it shall be the duty of such
departments to render assistance to the Board as may reasonably be required.
   (d)   Powers and Duties. The Board shall have the following powers and
duties pursuant to this section:
      (1)   To formulate, promulgate and adopt rules, policies, procedures, and
regulations governing the erection, construction, repair, alteration,
inspection, and maintenance of all buildings or classes of buildings, including
land area incidental thereto subject to the authority of the Building
Department as well as the installation of building materials within such
structures and the materials to be used in connection therewith. The Board,
shall on its own motion, or on application made by the Mayor or Building
Inspector, formulate, propose, adopt, modify, amend or repeal such rules,
policies, procedures and regulations to the extent necessary or desirable to
effectuate the purposes of the Department. The vote of a majority of the
members of the Board is required for the adoption of any rule, policy,
procedure or regulation, or amendment or annulment thereof.
      (2)   To formulate permits to be issued by the Department and to
establish reasonable fees for such permits, subject to review by Council, and
to assist the Building Inspector in reviewing all applications submitted for
such permits. The fee established for any permits and licenses shall bear some
reasonable relationship to the costs of such inspections and review.
      (3)   To establish licensing fees and permits within the Department,
subject to review by Council.
      (4)   To hear, conduct and decide appeals where it is alleged there is an
error in any order, requirement, decision or determination made by the Building
Inspector relating to any contractor license suspension, OBOA or BOCA
provisions, Ohio Plumbing Code, EPA regulations, permits, or any rule, policy,
procedure or regulation of this Board.
      (5)   To authorize any variances from the rules, policies, procedures, or
regulations adopted by this Board, including requirements relating to
contractor licensing or the enforcement of OBOA or BOCA provisions where such
variances will not be contrary to the public interest or where, owing to
special conditions or circumstances, a literal enforcement of this rule,
policy, procedure or regulation would result in unnecessary hardship in
accordance with the provisions of this section.
      (6)   To compile and publish, in the form of a model code, rules
pertaining to one-family, two-family and three-family dwelling houses which may
be incorporated into the Building Code and enforced by the Department.
      (7)   To conduct investigations of the necessity for any permits or
licenses required by the Department and the practicality of such permits or
licenses.
      (8)   To assist the Building Inspector, the Department and any and all
other City officials in implementing any rules, policies, procedures or
regulations created and adopted by this Board and in otherwise carrying out
such rules and regulations of this Board.
      (9)   To conduct all other actions or duties necessary for the
implementation of any rules, policies, procedures or regulations established by
this Board for enforcement by the Department or to otherwise carry out any
powers or duties granted to the Board.
   (e)   Decisions.
      (1)   The Board shall decide any appeals from the Building Inspector
within ten days after the final hearing thereon.
      (2)   The applicant shall be notified in writing of the Board’s decision
unless the decision is rendered orally and at the time of the hearing where the
applicant is present. The decision of the Board shall be binding upon the
Building Inspector and any other designated agent of the Department.
      (3)   The Board may reverse or affirm wholly or partially, or may modify
the order, requirements, decisions, or determination appealed from the Building
Inspector and shall make such order, requirement, decision or determination as
in its opinion ought to be made in the premises; and to that end, shall have
only those powers of the Building Inspector from whom the appeal was taken. Any
person adversely affected by a decision of the Board may appeal to the Common
Pleas Court within thirty days of receipt of the written notice of the Board’s
decision or the actual date of the Board’s decision if rendered orally.
         (Ord. 6-33-95. Passed 6-6-95; Ord. 12-102-99. Passed 12-21-99.)

   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section

132.08 FILE AND SALE COPIES.
   A complete copy of any building codes enforced by the Building Department,
including, but not limited to, the National Electric Code (NEC), the OBOA 1, 2,
and 3 Family Dwelling Code, the Building Officials and Code Administrators
National Property Maintenance Code (BOCA), the Ohio Basic Building Code (OBBC),
the Ohio Plumbing Code, the Circleville Building Code, and the Circleville
Zoning Code, as well as any amendments to these codes, shall be maintained on
file in the office of the Service Director, Safety Director, Building
Department, and by the Clerk of the Council for inspection by the public. At
least one copy of such code shall also be on file in the office of the City Law
Director, the County Law Library, and with the Judge of the Circleville
Municipal Court. In addition, the Building Department shall keep copies of such
codes available for distribution to the public at cost.
(Ord. 12-102-99. Passed 12-21-99.)
132.09 CONFLICTS OF LAWS.
   (a)    In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of any
building codes enforced by the Circleville Building Department and a provision
of state law, the State law shall control.
   (b)    In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of any
building code enforced by the Circleville Building Department and a provision
of a local ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation, the provisions of the
applicable building code shall control.
   (c)    In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of any
building code enforced by the Circleville Building Department and a provision
of any other technical code adopted by the City by reference, the stricter or
higher standard shall control.
(Ord. 12-102-99. Passed 12-21-99.)
132.10 SEVERABILITY AND VALIDITY.
   Sections and sub-sections of any building codes enforced by the Circleville
Building Department and several parts and provisions thereof are declared to be
independent sections, sub- sections, parts and provisions, and the holding of
any such section, sub-section, part or provision thereof to be
unconstitutional, void or ineffective for any cause shall not effect nor render
invalid any other such section, sub-section, part or provision thereof.
(Ord. 12-102-99. Passed 12-21-99.)
132.11 AUTHORITY TO ENTER.
   Upon presentation of proper credentials, any Building Inspector or his duly
authorized representatives, may enter at reasonable times any building,
structure or premises in the jurisdiction to perform any duty imposed upon him
by this chapter or any building code being enforced by the Circleville Building
Department. If requested entry is refused or is otherwise unobtainable, a
search warrant may be obtained with the aid of the Circleville Police
Department or the Pickaway County Sheriff's Department, where applicable,
before such entry or inspection is made.
(Ord. 12-102-99. Passed 12-21-99.)
132.12 RIGHT OF APPEAL.
   (a)    All persons shall have the right to appeal any decision, notice or
order of a Building Inspector of the City which relates to residential or
commercial structures. Residential appeals and appeals of issues under Property
Maintenance Chapter
1335 shall be made to the Building Advisory Board. Appeals of any decision,
notice or order of a Building Inspector of the City which relates to commercial
structures, except for appeals under Property Maintenance Chapter
1335, shall be made to the Ohio Board of Building Standards. The filing of an
appeal from a decision, notice or order shall suspend action on enforcement
until the appeal is acted upon.
   (b)   Each appellant or applicant and the Building Inspector, and any other
person whose interest may be affected by the appeal, shall be given a fair
opportunity to be heard orally, in person or by counsel, and to present written
arguments.
   (c)    Any person adversely affected may appeal a decision of a City
Building Inspector refusing to grant a permit or to permit the use of a
particular material and/or equipment or method of construction in a proposed
structure, provided such appeal is filed within fourteen days of the date of
receipt of the written decision from the Building Inspector. The appeal may
include proposed alternatives, modifications, or substitutions, complete plans
of structure, and other pertinent information and payment of fees.
      (1)    The appeal shall be based on one or both of the following grounds,
to-wit:
         A.   That the interpretation, filing, or order is erroneous or
constitutes an erroneous application of the particular provision of the
Building Code or related laws and ordinances involved, or is otherwise contrary
to law.
         B.   That a modified application or alternative arrangement is
available and feasible whereby the stricter application of a particular
provision may be modified with alternatives without defeating the public
safety, health and general welfare, purpose and intent of the Building Code or
related laws and ordinances involved.
      (2)    The hearing of any appeals relating to residential structures
shall be held within a reasonable time, but not to exceed thirty days following
receipt of the appeal by the Secretary of the Board. The Board shall provide
the appellant with written notice of its decision within ten days after the
final hearing and otherwise in accordance with Section
132.04(c) of the Codified Ordinances.
      (3)    The hearing of any appeals relating to commercial structures shall
be scheduled by the Ohio Board of Building Standards and will otherwise be
conducted according to the rules and regulations as established by the Ohio
Board of Building Standards.
         (Ord. 12-102-99. Passed 12-21-99.)
132.13  FEE FOR APPEAL OR ACTION.
   Each application for an appeal to the Ohio Board of Building Standards from
an action, decision, notice or order of a Building Inspector relating to
commercial structures shall be accompanied by a fee as established by the Ohio
Board of Building Standards. This fee shall be deposited with the office of the
Ohio Board of Building Standards and shall be used to defray the normal
expenses of the Board in conducting this appeal. No filing fee shall be charged
for any application for an appeal to the Building Department Board from an
action, decision, notice or order of a Building Inspector relating to
residential structures.
(Ord. 12-102-99. Passed 12-21-99.)
132.14 DELEGATION OF TESTS.
   The Building Inspector shall when he deems it desirable, request the
Chairman of the Building Advisory Board to designate members of the Board,
their designees or other qualified persons to make an investigation into the
facts and ramifications of an appeal and to make a report of the findings to
the Board.
(Ord. 12-102-99. Passed 12-21-99.)
132.15 STOP WORK ORDERS.
   Upon notice from a Building Inspector, work on any building, structure,
electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system that is being done contrary to
the provisions of this code shall immediately cease and shall not continue
until authorized by the Building Inspector, the Building Department, or a court
of competent jurisdiction, to proceed with the work. Such notice shall be in
writing and shall be given to the owner of the property, or to his agent, or to
the person doing the work, and shall state the specific violations and the
conditions under which work may be resumed.
(Ord. 12-102-99. Passed 12-21-99.)
132.16 PERSONAL NON-LIABILITY.
   Any suit brought against any officer or employee of the City because of any
act performed by him in the enforcement of any provisions of building codes
enforced by the Circleville Building Department shall be defended by the
Director of Law or the Attorney designated by the City's liability insurance
carrier until the final determination of the proceedings therein. The City
shall save such officer or employee harmless from personal liability unless
such employee acts outside the scope of his/her authority or is reckless in
that regard for any acts of ordinary negligence.
(Ord. 12-102-99. Passed 12-21-99.)
132.17 COOPERATION OF OTHER OFFICIALS.
   Any Building Inspector may request and shall receive so far as may be
necessary, in the discharge of his duties, the assistance and cooperation of
the Service Director in fixing grades, the Chief of Police in enforcing orders,
and the Director of Law in prosecuting violations.
(Ord. 12-102-99. Passed 12-21-99.)
132.18 SUBSTANTIAL REPAIR.
   The term "substantial repair" as referred to in any of the building codes
enforced by the Building Department is intended to mean any repair which
involves changes or major alterations to the building structure or to
mechanical, electrical, or plumbing systems.
(Ord. 12-102-99. Passed 12-21-99.)
132.19 PROCEDURES FOR RECEIPT OF FUNDS FOR FIRE LOSS INSURANCE PROCEEDS;
DEMOLITION OF UNSAFE BUILDINGS RESULTING FROM FIRE DESTRUCTION.
   Pursuant to the provisions of Ohio R.C. 3929.86 (C) and (D), no insurance
company doing business in the State shall pay a claim of a named insured for
fire damage to a structure located within the City where the amount recoverable
for the fire loss to the structure under all policies exceeds five thousand
dollars ($5,000) and the loss equals or exceeds sixty percent (60%) of the
aggregate limits of liability on all fire policies covering the building or
structure unless there is compliance with the following procedures:
   (a)   Where the loss agreed to between the named insured or insureds and the
company or companies equals or exceeds sixty percent (60%) of the aggregate
limits of liability on all fire policies covering the building or structure,
the insurance company or companies, in accordance with Ohio R.C. 715.26(F)
shall transfer from the insurance proceeds to the City Auditor in the aggregate
of two thousand dollars ($2,000) for each fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000),
and each fraction of that amount, of a claim, or, if, at the time of a proof of
loss agreed to between the named insured or insureds and the insurance company
or companies, the named insured or insureds have submitted a contractor's
signed estimate of the cost of removing, repairing or securing the building or
other structure, shall transfer from the insurance proceeds the amount
specified in the estimate. Such transfer of proceeds shall be on a pro rata
basis by all companies insuring the building or other structure. Policy
proceeds remaining after the transfer to the City shall be disbursed in
accordance with the policy terms. The named insured or insureds may submit a
contractor's signed estimate of the cost of removing, repairing or securing the
building or other structure after the transfer, and the designated officer
shall return the amount of the fund in excess of the estimate to the named
insured or insureds, provided that the City has not commenced to remove, repair
or secure the building or other structure. At the request of the owner/insured,
the chief building official will inspect the property after repair/demolition
and authorize the Auditor to return the deposit to the insured.
   (b)   Upon receipt of the proceeds by the City as authorized by this
section, the City Auditor shall place the proceeds in the City Treasury in a
separate fund to be used solely as security against the total cost of removing,
repairing or securing the building or structure incurred by the City, pursuant
to Ohio R.C. 715.261. When transferring the funds required by subsection (a)
hereof, an insurance company shall provide the City with the name and address
of the named insured or insureds, whereupon the City shall contact the named
insured or insureds, certify that the proceeds have been received by the City
and notify them that the following procedures will be followed:
      (1)    The funds shall be returned to the named insured or insureds when
repairs or removal or securing of the building or other structure have been
completed and the required proof received by the designated officer, if the
City has not incurred any cost for such repairs, removal or securing. If the
City has incurred any cost for repairs, removal or securing of the building or
other structure, such costs shall be paid from the fund and if excess funds
remain, the City shall transfer the remaining funds to the named insured or
insureds. Nothing herein shall be construed to limit the ability of the City to
recover any deficiency under Ohio R.C. 715.261.
      (2)    Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to prohibit the
municipal corporation and the named insured or insureds from entering into an
agreement that permits the transfer of funds to the named insured or insureds
if some other reasonable disposition of the damaged property has been
negotiated.
   (c)   Proof of payment by the company or companies of proceeds under a
policy in accordance with subsection (b) hereof is conclusive evidence of the
discharge of its obligation to the insured under the policy to the extent of
the payment and of compliance by the company or companies with subsection (b)
hereof.
   (d)   Nothing herein shall be construed to make an insurance company liable
for any amount in excess of proceeds payable under its insurance policy or for
any other act performed pursuant to this section, or to make the City or any of
its public officials an insured under a policy of insurance, or to create an
obligation to pay delinquent property taxes or unpaid liens or expenses other
than as provided in this section.
   (e)   An insurance company making payment of policy proceeds under this
section for structure removal liens or removal expenses incurred by the
municipal corporation shall have the full benefit of such payment including all
rights of subrogation and of assignment.
   (f)   As used in this section and Ohio R.C. 3929.87, "insurance company" or
"insurer'' includes the Ohio Fair Plan Underwriting Association as established
in Ohio R.C. 3929.43.
   (g)   This section shall be liberally construed to accomplish its purpose to
deter the commission of arson and related crimes, to discourage the abandonment
of property, and to prevent urban blight and deterioration.
      (Ord. 09-37-2011. Passed 9-6-11.)
132.99 VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   (a)   Any person, firm or corporation which violates or fails to comply with
any of the provisions of this chapter or of any of the building codes being
enforced by the City Building Department for which no other penalty has been
provided, or fails to comply with any order or regulation made thereunder, or
builds in violation of a building permit or certificate issued thereunder, or
occupies a structure without the required certificate of occupancy, is guilty
of a minor misdemeanor on the first offense and such person, firm or
corporation shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day
or portion thereof during which any violation or failure to comply with any of
the provisions of this chapter or of any of the building codes being enforced
by the City Building Department is committed, continued or permitted, and upon
conviction of any such violation or failure to comply, such person, firm or
corporation may be punished by a fine, or by contempt of court penalties, as
established by state or local laws.
   (b)   If, within one year of an initial violation or failure to comply with
any of the provisions of this chapter or of any of the building codes being
enforced by the City Building Department, the person, firm or corporation has
been previously convicted of or pled guilty to any violation or failure to
comply with any of the provisions of this chapter or of any of the building
codes being enforced by the City Building Department, then such person, firm or
corporation is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and may be
punishable by fine, or by imprisonment, or both such fine and imprisonment, as
established by state or local laws.
   (c)   If, within one year of an initial violation or failure to comply with
any of the provisions of this chapter or of any of the building codes being
enforced by the City Building Department, the person, firm or corporation has
been previously convicted of or pled guilty to two or more violations or
failures to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter or of any of the
building codes being enforced by the City Building Department, then such
person, firm or corporation is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree and
may be punishable by fine, or by imprisonment, or both such fine and
imprisonment, as established by state or local laws.
   (d)   The failure to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter or of
any of the building codes being enforced by the Circleville Building Department
and any violations of such provisions shall be deemed to be a strict liability
offense.
(Ord. 12-102-99. Passed 12-21-99.)

133.01 USE OF MONEYS DERIVED FROM VENDING MACHINES.
   All income derived from the vending of soft drinks, cigarettes, candies and
any other items of merchandise that may be vended through the use of vending
machines that are now or may be installed at the City Service Garage or City
Hall shall be placed in a special trust fund for the benefit of the Department
of Public Service and be used by the Department for the purchase of flowers, on
occasions deemed appropriate by the Department, and for the taking care of
other social amenities, customs and conventions on occasions deemed appropriate
by the Director of Public Service.
133.02 WORK WEEK; OVERTIME.
   The basic work week for the employees designated in the Department of Public
Service shall be forty hours per week; and the rate of pay shall be one and
one-half times the regular pay for all hours worked in excess of forty hours
per week for all classifications, notwithstanding Section
155.02.
(Ord. 13-76. Passed 1-20-76.)

133.04 DIRECTOR TO ADDRESS HANDICAPPED DISCRIMINATION COMPLAINTS.
   (a)   The City by previous administrative action established that the
Director of Public Service would serve as the Coordinator for Section 504 of
the Federal Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Section 504 Coordinator) requirements.
   (b)   The Section 504 Coordinator shall establish such forms and
instructions as necessary and shall make arrangements for the submission of
grievances by visually impaired, hearing impaired, and speech impaired persons
as are necessary.
   (c)   Any individual or group, except job applicants, may file in writing to
the Section 504 Coordinator, a complaint alleging discriminations on the basis
of violations of Section 504 of the Federal Rehabilitation Act of 1973, for
alleged discrimination on the basis of handicap in employment practices and
policies or in the providing of programs, services and benefits by the City.
   All such complaints, stating the full details thereof, shall be submitted
within thirty days of the alleged violation.
   (d)   Within fourteen calendar days of the receipt of the complaint as
stated in subsection (c) hereof, the Section 504 Coordinator shall respond in
writing or other acceptable methods understood by the complaintant. The
response will offer a resolution or explain the position of the City with
respect to the specific complaint.
   (e)   If the response, as required in subsection (d) hereof is not
sufficient, or does not satisfactorily resolve the issue, the complainant may
within fourteen calendar days of receipt of the response, request in writing a
hearing before the Handicapped Coordinating Committee. The Handicapped
Coordinating Committee shall consist of the Mayor, with whom the request is to
be filed, the Auditor, and the Director of Public Service of the City of
Circleville. Within fourteen calendar days after the filing of the complaint,
the Handicapped Coordinating Committee shall hold a hearing and respond in
writing to the complainant explaining the resolution of the complaint or the
position of the City, with respect to the complaint.
   (f)   If the response as required in subsection (e) hereof is not sufficient
or does not satisfactorily resolve the issue, the complainant may request
within fourteen days after receipt of the response in subsection (e) hereof, a
hearing before Council. Within thirty days after the hearing by Council,
Council shall respond in writing with the final resolution of the complaint.
Council's action shall be final.
   (g)   All records of complaints and proceedings, shall be maintained by the
City for a period of three years after the final resolution of any individual
complaint.
(Ord. 55-84. Passed 10-16-84.)
133.05 ODOT COOPERATIVE PURCHASING PROGRAM.
   (a)   This section shall be certified by the Clerk and forwarded to the
Director of the Department of Transportation as an official request pursuant to
Ohio R.C. 5513.01(B) seeking authorization to participate in the contract for
equipment.
   (b)   The Director is requested to look upon this request in the best
interest of the health, safety and welfare of the motoring public of the City.
   (c)   The Director of Public Service is hereby authorized to agree in the
name of the City, to be bound by all terms and conditions as the Director of
Transportation prescribes.
   (d)   The Director of Public Service is hereby authorized to agree in the
name of the City to directly pay the vendor, under each such contract of the
Ohio Department of Transportation in which the City participates, for items it
receives pursuant to the contract.
   (e)   Council shall authorize all purchases through this program over five
thousand dollars ($5,000).
(Ord. 12-103-91. Passed 12-3-91.)

135.01 COMPOSITION.
   (a)    Effective immediately upon the passage and approval of this
Ordinance, the Police Department of the City shall be composed of the following
officers and other members, who shall receive compensation provided for by
Ordinance:
      (1)   A Chief of the Police Department
      (2)   Two (2) Captains
      (3)   Four (4) Sergeants
      (4)   Twenty (20) Police Officers
      (5)   One (1) Communication Supervisor
      (6)   Six (6) Communications Officers (Ref Cod. Ord. 135.03)
      (7)   Two (2) Secretaries (Police Records Clerks) (Ref Cod. Ord. 135.04)
      (8)   One (1) Building/Fleet Maintenance (Ref Cod. Ord. 135.15)
      (9)   Fifteen (15) Reserve Police Unit (Ref Cod. Ord. 135.11)
      (10)   Ten (10) Part Time Police Officers (Ref Cod. Ord. 135.13)
      (11)   Four ( 4) Part Time Communications Officers (Ref Cod. Ord. 135.13)
      (12)   Two (2) Part Time Secretaries (Police Records Clerks) (Ref Cod.
Ord. 135.13)
   (b)    The Police Chief and each officer and other member of the Department,
required by law to be bonded, shall be covered by the blanket bond purchased by
the City.
   (c)    The Police Department, as constituted herein, shall be classified by
the Director of Public Safety, as required by law.
   (d)    That the position of Chief of Police within the Department of Public
Safety, Division of Police shall receive compensation as a full-time, non-
union, salaried, classified position and be paid under Pay Grade 8 of the
Uniform Compensation Plan for the Non-Bargaining Unit Employees.
   (e)    That the position of Captain within the Department of Public Safety,
Division of Police shall receive compensation as a full-time, non-union,
salaried, classified position and be paid under Pay Grade 8 of the Uniform
Compensation Plan for the Non-Bargaining Unit Employees.
   (f)    That the position of Sergeant, Police Officer and Communications
Officer within the Department of Public Safety, Division of Police shall
receive compensation as full-time, union, hourly, classified positions and be
paid per the OPBA Union Contract.
(Ord. 1-1-2025. Passed 1-7-25.)
135.02 AGE REQUIREMENTS.
   All persons qualified by the Civil Service Commission, who are at least the
age of twenty- one years, shall be eligible to receive an original appointment
to the Police Department.
(Ord. 11-101-92. Passed 11-3-92.)
135.03 COMMUNICATIONS OFFICERS.
   The Director of Public Safety is authorized to employ for the Department of
Public Safety, Division of Police a Communications Supervisor together with six
personnel to serve as Communications Officers. Each such Officer shall receive
compensation as full-time, union, hourly, classified position as established.
Each Officer will be assigned such duties as defined by the Safety Director,
Chief of Police and/or Communications Supervisor within the Communication
Center of the City. (Ord. 1-1-2025. Passed 1-7-25.)

   The Director of Public Safety is authorized to employ for the Department of
Public Safety, Division of Police, Two (2) Secretaries (Police Records Clerks)
positions. Each such Secretary shall receive compensation as full-time, union,
hourly, classified position as established. Each Secretary will be assigned
such duties as defined by the Safety Director and/or Chief of Police within the
Division of Police of the City.
(Ord. 1-1-2025. Passed 1-7-25.)

follows:
 
Level I Level II Level III Level IV

(Ord. 10-70-06. Passed 10-17-06.)
135.06 PRIVATE POLICE.
   The Chief of Police, with approval of the Director of Public Safety, when
good cause exists, may appoint special patrolmen or night watchmen for the
protection of private residential or business properties, areas or
establishment, provided that such appointees shall receive no compensation from
the Municipality and shall have first given bond to the City in the amount of
one thousand dollars ($1,000). Such appointees shall have the powers of
patrolmen and such appointees while on duty may wear such police uniform and
insignia and carry such arms as the Director of Public Safety may prescribe.
Such appointment may be rescinded at any time by the Chief of Police or by
resolution of Council.
(Ord. 4185. Passed 8-23-56.)

135.08 WORK WEEK; OVERTIME.
   The annual salaries of Law Enforcement Officers shall be figured at forty
hours per week; and all Law Enforcement Officers below the rank of Captain
shall receive time and one-half for all hours worked over 40 hours per week,
notwithstanding Section
155.02.
(Ord. 12-97-00. Passed 12-19-00.)
135.09 RESIDENCY REQUIREMENT OF POLICE CHIEF.
   Pursuant to the Ohio Revised Code Section 9.481(B), the Council of the City
of Circleville hereby waives the requirement of residency of the position of
the Chief of Police under the following conditions:
   (a)   That their current residence is within the Pickaway County or any
County adjacent to Pickaway County, State of Ohio, so that in the event of an
emergency the applicant would be able to report within a reasonable time frame.
      (Ord. 07-48-2024. Passed 7-16-24.)
135.10 POLICE PROTECTION FOR FACILITIES AND REAL ESTATE USED FOR MUNICIPAL
PURPOSES LOCATED OUTSIDE THE MUNICIPALITY.
   (a)   The Director of Public Safety and Police Chief are hereby authorized
to provide any necessary police protection to the waste water treatment plant
facilities as well as all other real estate of the City being used for
municipal purposes which lies outside of the Municipal corporation limits
pursuant to Ohio R.C. 715.50.
   (b)   The Chief of Police or any of his police officers are hereby
authorized and directed to prosecute any violations of City ordinance or of the
statutes of the State of Ohio in the Circleville Municipal Court which occur on
the real estate owned by the City located outside the Municipal limits.
(Ord. 02-12-99. Passed 2-16-99.)
135.11 RESERVE POLICE.
   (a)    Appointment of Members. The Director of Public Safety is hereby
authorized to commission up to fifteen (15) persons as is necessary to
supplement and support the regular police force, to serve as reserve police
officers. These reserve officers shall be known as the "Reserve Police Unit".
   (b)    Term of Service. Reserve police officers shall serve at the pleasure
of the Director of Public Safety, or until such time as a resignation is
submitted by the reserve officer and accepted by the Director of Public Safety.
   (c)    Qualification of Members. The members of the Reserve Police Unit must
be at least twenty-one (21) years of age at the time of their appointment and
shall meet such other requirements as provided by the rules and regulations set
forth in subsection (e) hereof.
   (d)    Control of Unit. The Chief of Police shall be the commanding officer
and shall have control over the assignment, training, stationing and direction
of all members of the Reserve Police Unit. The Reserve Police Unit shall have
all police powers but shall perform only such police duties as are assigned to
them by the Chief of Police. Reserve officers shall only act in such capacity
while in prescribed uniform or a portion of such uniform. The Chief of Police
shall prescribe the time and place such uniforms or portions thereof shall be
worn. Reserve members shall obey the chain of command of the Police Department
and take official police orders from all regular appointed members thereof.
   (e)    Rules and Regulations. The Chief of Police, under the direction of
the Director of Public Safety, shall prescribe the rules and regulations for
the organization, administration, conduct and control of the Reserve Police
Unit.
   (f)    Uniform. The Chief of Police is authorized by the prescribed rules
and regulations, to determine what type of uniform or part thereof shall be
worn by members of the Reserve Police Unit.
   (g)    Compensation.
      (1)   All services performed by reserve police officers for the City of
Circleville shall be on a voluntary basis.
      (2)   Reserve police officers shall be paid one dollar ($1.00) annually
on the anniversary date of their commission.
      (3)   Reserve police officers may be authorized to work special duty
assignments paid by an entity other than the City of Circleville, such as
school events, church events, Pumpkin Show details, etc., at the discretion of
the Chief of Police.
      (4)   Reserve police officers are not entitled to any part-time benefits
or any relief or pension funds of the City or the State of Ohio, or any other
similar benefits. Notwithstanding the foregoing, reserve police officers shall
be entitled to any and all relief under Ohio Workers' Compensation.
   (h)    Use of Uniform. No reserve police officer shall appear in public in
uniform unless scheduled or called to duty by the Safety Director, Chief of
Police or other officer in charge of the Police Department.
   (i)    Duty Assignments. During periods of emergency call out, reserve
police officers shall assist members of the Police Department by performing
whatever functions are necessary to protect life and property as may be
assigned by the Police Department shift officer in charge. Reserve police
officers may work other non-emergency jobs only as approved and scheduled to
the Police Department. Reserve officers shall not work in place of regular
officers of the City of Circleville to maintain minimum staffing levels.
   (j)    Reserve Liaison Officer. The Chief of Police may appoint a member of
the Police Department to be in charge of the Reserve Police Unit. The member of
the Police Department serving in this capacity shall be known as the Reserve
Liaison Officer.
   (k)    Non-Liability. This section is declared by Council as an exercise by
the City of its police powers for the protection of the public peace, health,
property, safety and general welfare. Neither the City, nor any agent or
representative of the City, an officer appointed under the provisions of this
section, or any individual, firm, partnership, corporation or the receiver,
trustee, or any agent thereof, who in good faith executes any executive order,
rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this section,
shall be liable for injury or damages sustained to persons or property as the
direct proximate result of such action. In addition to any other
responsibilities or immunities, the members of the Reserve Police Unit shall
bear the same responsibilities and the same immunities as any other regularly
employed member of the Police Department, except as herein provided.
(Ord. 1-1-2025. Passed 1-7-25.)
135.12 INSPECTION FEE FOR UNDER SPEED VEHICLES INCLUDING GOLF CARTS.
   There is hereby established an inspection fee for under speed vehicles,
including golf carts, in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00), which fee shall
be collected by the Police Department at the time of such vehicle inspection
and deposited into the Safety Fund of the City to be used to defray the
expenses of the inspection program and such other law enforcement expenses as
may be necessarily incurred as a result of these vehicle inspections.
(Ord. 07-44-2008. Passed 7-15-08.)
135.13 PART TIME POLICE DEPARTMENT POSITIONS.
   (a)    Appointment of Positions. The Director of Public Safety is hereby
authorized to accept applications when necessary to fill part time positions
within the Police Department of the City to include ten (10) part time sworn
Police Officers, four (4) part time Communications Officers and two (2) part
time Secretaries (Police Records Clerks) positions.
   (b)   Term of Service. Part time positions within the Police Department
serve at the pleasure of the Director of Public Safety or until such time as a
resignation is submitted by the part time employee and accepted by the City of
Circleville.
   (c)   Duties. The part time employees shall perform such duties and
assignments as are specifically assigned or as prescribed by the Chief of
Police.
   (d)   Rank. All part time sworn Police Officers of the City shall hold the
rank of patrolmen.
   (e)   Compensation. Part time employees within the Police Department shall
be paid in accordance with the established pay scale set forth in various union
contracts for positions of the same classification. Part time employees are
non-union, non-civil service positions and shall receive no fringe benefits or
pension funds of the City or the State of Ohio, or any other similar benefits.
Notwithstanding the forgoing, part time positions within the Police Department
shall be entitled to any and all relief under the Ohio Workers Compensation
other than the compensation pay rate no other benefits from the union apply to
this position.
   (f)   Maximum Hours. No part time employee shall work more than 120 hours
per month or 1,440 hours per calendar year.
   (g)   Special Duty. Part time sworn Police Officers and Communications
Officers shall only be offered overtime and special duty after the full-time
Police Officers and Communications Officers have been offered it and did not
take it.
   (h)   Qualifications. Part time employees of the Police Department shall
have the same qualifications as the full-time positions within the department
and shall be required to undergo the same background investigation as full-time
employees.
   (i)   Discipline. Part time positions within the Police Department shall be
under the disciplinary jurisdiction of the Chief of Police. Part time positions
serve at the discretion of the Director of Public Safety and shall not have any
property rights in said employment and may be removed by the duly authorized
City authorities at any time. Part time employees shall comply with all
applicable rules and general orders issued by the City of Circleville Police
Department.
   (j)   Law Enforcement Powers. Any person appointed as a part time police
officer shall have such powers of law enforcement and arrest and authority to
bear arms as are accorded to full-time members of the department of the police
when appearing in their capacity of their employment.
(Ord. 06-40-2024. Passed 6-4-24; Ord. 1-1-2025. Passed 1-7-25.)
135.14 POLICE CADET CORPS.
   (a)   There is hereby established a Police Cadet Corp within the Department
of Public Safety, Division of Police, the members of which shall be appointed
by the Chief of Police.
   (b)   Members of the Police Cadet Corp shall be at least eighteen (18) years
of age; successfully complete polygraph and psychological screening; pass a
medical exam and drug screen; complete Police Academy and receive an OPOTA
Certificate; sign a reimbursement agreement to reimburse the entire amount of
the city's cost for training, in the event such Cadet does not stay with the
city for a period of three (3) years or more after appointment; and meet such
other requirements as provided for by the rules and regulations established by
the Chief of Police.
   (c)   The Chief of Police shall be the commanding officer of the Cadet Corps
and shall have control over the assignment, training and direction of work of
the Corp. The Cadet Corp shall perform only such police assignments or duties
as assigned by the Chief of Police and shall act only when in the prescribed
uniform. The Cadet Corp members shall only obey the chain of command of the
Police Department and take orders from all regularly appointed members of the
Police Department. Cadet Corp members shall not be permitted to carry or use
any firearm in the performance of his duties except that he may be taught the
proper use of firearms as part of his training.
   (d)   The Police Cadets shall attend the police academy to obtain their
police training and OPOTA certificate at the City's expense and upon graduation
from the academy will be employed by the city as a first pay step police
officer.
   (e)   The position of the Police Cadet shall be a fulltime, non-union
position with the starting pay as set by Council and shall be paid thereafter
in accordance with the City's compensation plan.
(Ord. 07-39-2023. Passed 7-18-23.)
135.15 BUILDING/FLEET MAINTENANCE.
   (a)   The Director of Public Safety is authorized to employ for the
Department of Public Safety, Division of Police a Building/Fleet Maintenance
employee and shall receive compensation as a full-time, union, hourly,
classified position. The Building/Fleet Maintenance employee will be assigned
such duties as defined by the Safety Director, Chief of Police and/or Sergeant
within the Division of Police of the City.
(Ord. 1-1-2025. Passed 1-7-25.)

137.01 COMPOSITION.
   (a)   Effective immediately, the Division of Fire and EMS of the City shall
be composed of the following positions, who shall receive salaries as provided
for by ordinance:
      (1)   One Fire Chief;
      (2)   Three Captains;
      (3)   Three Lieutenants;
      (4)   Eighteen Firefighters;
      (5)   Two Paramedics; and
      (6)   Eighteen part-time Firefighters.
   In addition to the employees listed above, the Division of Fire and EMS
shall maintain a roster of volunteers to perform fire and EMS duties. These
volunteers may be provided a per run stipend and other nominal benefits in
accordance with Fair Labor Standards Act, 29 U.S.C. Section 201, et seq. (Ord.
11-90-2022. Passed 11-15-22; Ord. 11-86-24. Passed 11-5-24.)
   (b)   The blanket bond purchased by the City shall cover the Chief, each
officer and other members of the Fire and EMS Department required by law to be
bonded.
(Ord. 04-15-2005. Passed 4-19-05.)
137.02 ADVISORY BOARD.
   (a)   There is hereby created a volunteer Advisory Board. This board has the
authority to review issues and make recommendations to the Fire Chief and
Safety Director regarding work performed by volunteers.
   (b)   The Advisory Board shall consist of the following individuals:
      (1)   Medical Director of the service (non-voting).
      (2)   Secretary of the Board.
      (3)   Three EMS volunteer representatives.
      (4)   Three Fire volunteer representatives.
   Members (2), (3) and (4) above shall be elected by the volunteers on an
annual basis.
   (c)   The Medical Director shall have the executive authority to promulgate
medical rules, regulations, quality assurance standards, continuing education
or re-training requirements to assure continuing compliance with the “standards
of care” promulgated by the Ohio Emergency Medical Board, the Ohio Chapter of
the Association of Emergency Physicians, and the Ohio Chapter of the
Association of Air Medical Services of the United States Department of
Transportation. Such rules and regulations shall apply to all EMT’s of the City
of Circleville, Division of Fire and EMS.
   (d)   The Medical Director of the Division of Fire and EMS shall receive
reasonable stipend pay for the services provided while on the Advisory Board of
the organization. This reasonable stipend pay shall be established by the
Safety Director, with the advice and consent of Council, and shall be paid from
the budget of the Division of Fire and EMS on an appropriate schedule. The
Medical Director shall be selected by the Safety Director and Fire Chief. The
Medical Director serves at the pleasure of the Safety Director.
(Ord. 04-15-2005. Passed 4-19-05.)
137.03 AGE REQUIREMENTS.
   All persons qualified by the Civil Service Commission between the ages of 18
and 36 years shall be eligible to receive an original appointment as a
firefighter/EMT. Volunteers and EMT/Paramedics older than 36 would still
qualify to continue performing functions for the City.
(Ord. 04-15-2005. Passed 4-19-05.)
137.04 FIRE AND EMS RECORDS.
   (a)   The Chief of the Division of Fire shall keep in convenient form a
complete record of all fires. Such records shall include the time of the alarm;
the location of the fire; the cause of the fire, if known; the type of
buildings; the name of the owner and tenant; the purpose for which it is
occupied; the value of the building and the contents; the members of the
department responding to the alarm; and such other information as he may deem
advisable or as may be required.
   (b)   The Chief shall also be responsible for insuring the EMS records are
maintained in accordance with applicable law. The Chief, along with the Medical
Director, shall insure that all applicable reporting requirements are met.
(Ord. 04-15-2005. Passed 4-19-05.)
137.05 AVAILABILITY.
   Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to impose a “legal duty” upon the
City to provide fire or emergency medical services to any person. To the extent
possible, considering the personnel available, equipment availability and
competing priorities, the City shall provide such equipment, volunteer and/or
paid personnel and training as is deemed appropriate to sustain the operation
of the City of Circleville Division of Fire and EMS, including but not limited
to, the following:
   (a)   Ambulances or such other public safety vehicles as are in compliance
with standards implemented by the Ohio Emergency Medical Services Board.
   (b)   Emergency medical equipment, light rescue, airway, maintenance
equipment, cardiac monitoring and defibrillation equipment, intravenous therapy
products and such drugs as prescribed by the Medical Director which shall all
be in compliance with any and all standards established by the Ohio Emergency
Medical Services Board.
   (c)   Communications equipment necessary to receive dispatch requests to
communicate to the hospital emergency room or other medical control during
emergencies and from person to person when engaged in emergency medical
services or rescue operations. Such equipment shall conform to those
requirements of the Ohio Emergency Medical Services Board of Federal
Communications Commission for the region.
   (d)   Such training and continuing medical education as is necessary to
insure continuing competence of the medical personnel in compliance with the
licensing and the renewal requirements of the State of Ohio and the Medical
Director.
   (e)   Repair and continuing maintenance services for the Emergency Medical
Service including general operating requirements for disposal supplies,
facilities, and fuel.
      (Ord. 04-15-2005. Passed 4-19-05.)
137.06 FIRE PREVENTION BUREAU.
   (a)   The Chief is authorized to establish a Fire Prevention Bureau and
designate a member of the Fire Department as the Department’s Fire Prevention
Bureau Administrator- Inspector.
   (b)   While functioning as Administrator-Inspector, such member of the Fire
Department may be assigned to work a regular forty hour week at such times as
the Chief may prescribe. The Chief and/or the Director of Public Safety must
authorize overtime not generated at a fire scene.
   (c)   The manning docket authorized for the Division of Fire after the
establishment and during the operation of such bureau shall be set forth in
Section
137.01(a).
   (d)   The Chief may have the Administrator-Inspector trained to comply with
any applicable provision of Ohio law.
(Ord. 04-15-2005. Passed 4-19-05.)
137.07 WORKERS’ COMPENSATION.
   Volunteers will be subject to workers’ compensation benefits in accordance
with applicable law.
(Ord. 04-15-2005. Passed 4-19-05.)
137.08 SERVICE AND MUTUAL AID CONTRACTS.
   The Safety Director, with the advice and consent of Council, is hereby
authorized to enter into contracts for supplementary service in time of
extraordinary demand and/or mutual aid contracts with surrounding governmental
units. Extra territorial service should be limited to such as is covered by
contract or, in the event no contract exists, then only if life is immediately
in jeopardy, but not merely to provide a higher level of medical care than
exists in the jurisdiction at the election of the officials of such
jurisdiction. Primary coverage shall inure to the benefit of the City, its
citizens and those areas under contract.
(Ord. 04-15-2005. Passed 4-19-05.)
137.09 QUALIFIED PERSONNEL TO FURNISH EMS SERVICES.
   In addition to the general duties assigned to the firefighter and officers,
the members who have appropriate training and are qualified to serve as
Emergency Medical Technicians are hereby permitted to furnish emergency medical
services on behalf of the City when necessary. These trained personnel are
permitted to use all EMT equipment and vehicles when carrying out such EMT
duties. (Ord. 04-15-2005. Passed 4-19-05.)
137.10 QUALIFIED PERSONNEL TO FURNISH FIRE FIGHTER SERVICES.
   Emergency Medical Technicians who have appropriate training and are
qualified to serve as fire fighters are hereby permitted to serve as fire
fighters when necessary. These trained personnel are permitted to use all fire
fighting equipment and vehicles when carrying out such fire fighter duties and
shall be supervised by the fire officer or officers in charge.
(Ord. 04-15-2005. Passed 4-19-05.)
137.11 INSPECTION FEES.
   (a)   Foster/Adoption Home Inspections- $25.00
 
   (b)   Reinspection of Commercial Buildings - first reinspection - no charge
 
   (c)   Reinspection of Commercial Buildings - second and subsequent
reinspection - $100.00
 
   (d)   Fire Alarm and/or Sprinkler Acceptance Test- $100.00
 
   (e)   Life Safety Acceptance Inspection- $100.00
 
   (f)   Occupancy Inspection- $50.00
 
   (g)   Fire Works Inspection- $200.00
 
   (h)   Plans Review- $50.00
(Ord. 07-42-2018. Passed 7-17-18.)
137.12 FEES FOR SERVICES; BILLING AND COLLECTION.
   (a)   Fees for Emergency Medical Transport Services. The fees set forth
herein shall be established and implemented for the following Emergency Medical
Services originating from anywhere within the City's corporate limits effective
immediately upon the passage of this section;
      (1)   Advance Life Support ("ALS"): $850.00 per patient transported plus
$14.53 per loaded mile from the location of patient pick-up to the hospital.
      (2)   Advance Life Support II ("ALS"): $1,125.00 per patient transported
plus $14.53 per loaded mile from the location of patient pick-up to the
hospital.
      (3)   Basic Life Support ("BLS"): $690.00 per patient transported plus
$14.53 per loaded mile from the location of patient pick-up to the hospital
      (4)   EMS Response Without Transportation: No Charge
      (5)   The City or its Billing Agent shall bill the patient or the
responsible party for any emergency medical services rendered in accordance
with the State or Federal guidelines. Residents of the City of Circleville will
be required to pay to the extent of their private or public medical insurance
coverage. Co-payments and deductibles will not be sought from residents of the
City of Circleville. Your taxes are considered as payment for co-payments and
deductibles. Non-residents of the City of Circleville will be billed for any
co-payments and deductibles. In the event the non-resident does not have
insurance, they will be responsible for the full amount of the bill.
   (b)   Factors Considered by Billing and/or Collection Agency. In handling
the billing and collecting services for emergency medical transport services,
the following factors shall be considered by the billing and/or collection
agency.
      (1)   Indigent individuals should be considered for Waivers.
      (2)   Special hardship situations should be considered for payment plans
or special arrangements.
      (3)   Uninsured patients not on Medicaid or Medicare may be referred to
the Department of Jobs and Family Services to determine eligibility for
coverage.
      (4)   An account with more than $100.00 owing shall be sent to collection
if no response has been received requesting insurance information or patient
has not contacted the billing agency to make payment arrangements within ninety
(90) of the request.
      (5)   Each case shall be reviewed for special circumstances on a case by
case basis.
         (Ord. 03-08-2020. Passed 3-24-20.)

139.03 WASTEWATER SUPERINTENDENT.
   (a)   The Wastewater Superintendent is eligible for all benefits to which a
full-time employee of the City is entitled under Chapter
155, except that the Superintendent shall be considered as "supervisory

157, shall not be eligible to participate as a member of or a counsel to an
employee organization or unit thereof.
   (b)   The Superintendent shall have such qualifications as will permit him
or her to fulfill the regulatory requirements regarding operator certification.
(Ord. 90-79. Passed 11-20-79.)
139.04 HEARING PROCEDURES.
   (a)   Definitions. For purposes of this section, except as otherwise
provided, the following words shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to
them in this section.
      (1)   “Consumer” means any person who is the ultimate user of water
utility services provided by the City.
      (2)   “Customer” means any person who enters into a contractual agreement
with the City to receive or to pay for utility services provided by the City.
Customers may, but need not, be consumers of the services provided under such a
contractual agreement.
      (3)   “Billing Address” means the address at which the customer
contractually liable for utility services furnished to a service address
receives billings from the City. Billing addresses may, but need not, be the
address at which such services are received.
      (4)   “Service Address” means any individual address at which water
utility services are furnished a consumer or customer. The singular may include
the plural. Most service addresses will be individually metered. However, in
some buildings one meter may supply more than one benefitted unit. In such
circumstances, each individual benefitted unit is a separate service address as
that term is used herein. In any case where one meter supplies more than one
benefitted unit, the customer shall be the owner or legally authorized agent of
the owner of the premises.
      (5)   “Consumer Benefitted Unit” means any service address in which the
customer who is contractually liable for utility services furnished that
address does not reside.
      (6)   “Customer Benefitted Unit” means any service address in which the
customer contractually liable for utility services furnished that address
resides.
   (b)   Role of Director of Public Utilities. The Director of Public Utilities
shall be the initial contact person for anyone who has a question or dispute
about an application for water and/or sewer services; a termination or proposed
termination of water and/or sewer services; a billing question; payment
requirements; or other department requirements for obtaining or maintaining
water and/or sewer services which cannot otherwise be resolved by other
employees of the Department of Public Utilities. The Director of Public
Utilities shall strive to make reasonable arrangements to provide water and/or
sewer services; arrange reasonable alternate methods of payment, or reasonable
security for payment, in order to preserve utility service, and shall supply
and maintain residential utility service without discrimination.
   (c)   Right of Appeal.
      (1)   Appeal to Mayor. All customers, consumers, and applicants for water
and/or sewer services shall have the right to appeal to the Mayor any decision,
notice or order of the Department of Public Utilities which has not been
satisfactorily resolved by the Director of Public Utilities.
      (2)   Representation. Customers, consumers or applicants for water and/or
sewer services shall be given a fair opportunity to be heard orally, in person
or by counsel, and may present documentary and oral information for
consideration. Persons appealing a decision of the Director of Public Utilities
shall be entitled to reasonable access to city business records concerning the
affected service address in order to prepare for the hearing, including the
right to obtain copies of documents upon payment of the actual cost of copying.
      (3)   Application for Appeal or Action. Any person adversely affected may
appeal a decision of the Director of Public Utilities, including, but not
limited to, billing disputes, denials of service, proposed termination of
utility services, and/or requests for restoration of utility services, provided
such appeal is filed within fourteen days of any decision of the Director of
Public Utilities. An appeal request is made whenever a person notifies the
Director of Public Utilities or his/her representative, orally or in writing,
that such person disagrees with the decision of the Director of Public
Utilities. If the Director receives an oral hearing request, the request shall
be reduced to writing by the consumer or customer within fourteen days and
immediately forwarded to the Mayor for hearing.
   (d)   Hearing. The hearing of any appeals relating to decisions of the
Director of Public Utilities shall be held within a reasonable time, not to
exceed five business days following the receipt by the Director of a verbal or
written appeal request. The Mayor or his representative, shall provide the
person notice of the time and place of the hearing for such appeal at least one
full business day in advance of the hearing. The Mayor shall grant a consumer’s
request for a continuance of the hearing for a period not to exceed ten
business days.
   (e)   Powers of Mayor. The Mayor shall have the power, when good cause is
shown, to approve applications for service; compromise and adjust billings;
negotiate, defer and compromise disputes as to payment demand; and to cancel
termination and/or order restoration of utility services.
   (f)   Decision of Mayor.
      (1)   The Mayor shall make a written decision after the hearing, which
shall include the information presented at the hearing and the reasons for the
decision. A copy of the decision shall be delivered to the person appealing and
a copy retained in the business files kept by the City relating to any service
address affected by the hearing.
      (2)   The hearing decision shall be sent to the person appealing within a
reasonable time after the hearing, not to exceed fourteen days.
      (3)   If a hearing has been requested prior to actual termination of
utility service, no termination may occur until seven days after the hearing
decision is sent to the person appealing.
         (Ord. 03-23-01. Passed 3-20-01.)
CHAPTER 140
Department of Cable Television Affairs
140.01   Created; purpose.
140.02   Director’s position created; duties; appointment.

140.01 CREATED; PURPOSE.
   There is hereby created a Department of Cable Television Affairs within the
City to administer and supervise the cable television access channels
oeprations within the City, to oversee the Cable Television Special Revenue
Fund and to enforce the cable franchise, Federal and State laws relative to
cable television, and provide for government, community and educational access
programming.
(Ord. 3-11-95. Passed 3-7-95.)
140.02 DIRECTOR’S POSITION CREATED; DUTIES; APPOINTMENT.
   There is hereby created within the Cable Television Affairs Department a
Director of Cable Television Affairs for the City who shall be responsible for
the administration and supervision of the entire cable television access
channels operations within the City and shall have such other duties and
responsibilities as established by the Cable Television Commission of
Circleville. The Director shall be appointed by and report directly to the
Mayor.
(Ord. 3-11-95. Passed 3-7-95.)
140.03 CLASSIFICATION OF DIRECTOR.
   The position of Director of Cable Television Affairs ceated herein shall be
a part-time, unclassified exempt position and shall be paid from the Cable
Television Personnel Account No. 211.0411.51000.
(Ord. 3-11-95. Passed 3-7-95.)
140.04 DIRECTOR QUALIFICATIONS.
   The position of a Director of Cable Television Affairs within the Department
of Cable Television Affairs shall be advertised in The Circleville Herald and a
person employed who has the requisite training and qualifications for the
position, including the knowledge of FCC rules and government policies
regarding cable television and broadcasting and otherwise complies with the
specifications for such position established by the Cable Television Commission
of the City.
(Ord. 3-11-95. Passed 3-7-95.)
140.05 DIRECTOR’S SALARY.
   Upon hiring, the Director of Cable Television Affairs shall be paid an
annual salary of twelve thousand five hundred dollars ($12,500) as set upon
recommendation of the Cable Television Commission of the City.
(Ord. 3-11-95. Passed 3-7-95.)

members, consisting of the Mayor, Director of Public Service, the President of
the Board of Park Commissioners, and four citizens of the municipal corporation
who shall serve without compensation and be appointed by the Mayor for terms of
six years each. At least two citizen members of the Commission shall be
appointed every third year. The Commission shall elect its own officers
annually. The composition and appointment of the Commission shall be in
accordance with Ohio R.C. 713.01.
(Ord. 9-65-91. Passed 9-3-91.)

141.03 COMMISSION ORGANIZATION, RULES AND HEARINGS.
   The City Planning and Zoning Commission shall organize annually and elect a
Chairman, Vice Chairman and Secretary who may, within budgetary limitations,
retain the services of a Recording Secretary. The Commission shall adopt from
time to time such rules and regulations as it may deem necessary to carry into
effect the provisions of the zoning ordinances. The hearings of the Commission
may go into executive session for discussion, but not for vote, on any case
before it. The Commission shall hear any owner of property with a substantial
interest in any matter before the Commission. The Chairman and all other voting
members of the Commission shall vote on any and all matters before the
Commission. A majority of the seven members of the Commission shall constitute
a quorum and when only four members are present the unanimous vote of all four
shall be required to take action under or interpretation of the Zoning
Ordinance by any administrative officer of the City.
(Ord. 9-65-91. Passed 9-3-91.)
141.04 COMMISSION MINUTES AND RECORDS.
   The City Planning and Zoning Commission shall keep minutes of its
proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon each question; or if absent
or failing to vote, indicating such facts; and shall keep records of its
examinations and other official actions, all of which shall be preserved as a
public record. All witnesses before the Commission shall be placed under oath
by the Recording Secretary who shall be a Notary Public, or another Notary
Public in the absence of the Recording Secretary.
(Ord. 9-65-91. Passed 9-3-91.)
141.05 WITNESSES, OATHS, CONTEMPT AND DOCUMENTS BEFORE COMMISSION.
    The City Planning and Zoning Commission shall have the power to subpoena
witnesses, administer oaths and punish for contempt, and may require the
production of documents, under such regulations as it may establish.
(Ord. 9-65-91. Passed 9-3-91.)
141.06 DEPARTMENT ASSISTANCE TO COMMISSION.
   The City Planning and Zoning Commission may call upon the Mayor and, through
the Mayor, any department of the City to render such assistance to the
Commission as may reasonably be required.
(Ord. 9-65-91. Passed 9-3-91.)
141.07 ESTABLISHMENT OF BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS.
   There is hereby established a Board of Zoning Appeals of seven members,
consisting of the Mayor, Director of Public Services, President of Board of
Park Commissioners, and four citizens of the municipal corporation who shall be
those same persons as appointed by the Mayor to the City Planning and Zoning
Commission, shall serve without compensation, and shall be appointed by the
Mayor for terms of six years each. The Board shall elect its own officers
annually and shall otherwise comply with Ohio R.C. 713.11.
(Ord. 9-65-91. Passed 9-3-91.)
141.08 BOARD ORGANIZATION, RULES AND HEARINGS.
   The Board of Zoning Appeals shall organize annually and elect a Chairman,
Vice Chairman and Secretary who may, within budgetary limitations, retain the
services of a Recording Secretary. The officers of the Board, may hold the same
position as officers of the City Planning and Zoning Commission. The Board may
adopt from time to time such rules and regulations as it may deem necessary to
carry into effect the provisions of the City zoning ordinances. The hearings of
the Board shall be public. However, the hearings of the Board may go into
executive session for discussion, but not for vote, on any case before it. The
Board shall hear any owner of property adjacent to the lot for which the
granting of any application is pending and shall also hear any other parties
having a substantial interest as determined by the Board. The Chairman and all
other voting members of the Board shall vote on any and all matters before the
Commission. A majority of the seven members of the Board shall constitute a
quorum and when only four members are present the unanimous vote of all four
shall be required to take any action under or interpretation of the zoning
ordinance by any administrative officer of the City.
(Ord. 9-65-91. Passed 9-3-91.)
141.09 MINUTES AND RECORDS OF BOARD.
   The Board of Zoning Appeals shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing
the vote of each member upon each question; or if absent or failing to vote,
indicating such facts; and shall keep records of its examinations and other
official actions, all of which shall be preserved as a public record. All
witnesses before the Board shall be placed under oath by the Recording
Secretary who shall be a Notary Public or another Notary Public in the absence
of the Recording Secretary. (Ord. 9-65-91. Passed 9-3-91.)
141.10 WITNESSES, OATHS, CONTEMPT AND DOCUMENTS BEFORE THE BOARD.
    The Board of Zoning Appeals shall have the power to subpoena witnesses,
administer oaths and punish for contempt and may require the production of
documents, under such regulations as it may establish. (Ord. 9-65-91. Passed 9-
3-91.)
141.11 DEPARTMENT ASSISTANCE TO BOARD.
   The Board of Zoning Appeals may call upon the Mayor and, through the Mayor,
any department of the City to render such assistance to the Board as may
reasonably be required.
(Ord. 9-65-91. Passed 9-3-91.)
141.12 BOARD DECISIONS.
   (a)   The Board of Zoning Appeals shall decide all applications and appeals
within ten days after the final hearing thereon.
   (b)   The applicant shall be notified in writing of the Board's decision
unless the decision is rendered orally at the time of the hearing where the
applicant is present. The decision of the Board shall be binding upon the
Service Director, Building Inspector or designated person.
   (c)   The Board may reverse or affirm wholly or partially, or may modify the
order, requirements, decisions or determinations appealed from and shall make
such order, requirement, decision or determination as in its opinion ought to
be made in the premises; and to that end, shall have only those powers of the
municipal official from whom the appeal was taken. Any person adversely
affected by a decision of the Board may appeal to Council by filing notice upon
the Clerk of the Council within thirty days of receipt of the written notice of
the Board's decision or the actual date of the Board's decision if rendered
orally.
(Ord. 9-65-91. Passed 9-3-91.)
141.13 ADOPTION OF CIRCLEVILLE EAST LAND USE PLAN.
   Council hereby adopts the Circleville East Land Use Plan, as created by
James L. Hartzler, and as forwarded for approval by the Circleville Planning
and Zoning Commission and Board of Zoning Appeals, for use in determining
future development of the Eastern Annexation area.
(Ord. 05-40-94. Passed 5-3-94.)
