701.01 BUSINESS HOURS.
   (a)   No owner of any place of business, situated in any of the residential
zone classifications of the City or any agent or employee of such owner, shall
permit his place of business to be open for operations at any time other than
between the hours of 5:00 a.m. and 1:00 a.m. on any day of the year.
 
   (b)   However, the closing hours designated in subsection (a) herein shall
not apply to any place of business situated in any residential zone
classification that is operating under any liquor license issued by the Board
of Liquor Control of the State of Ohio in accordance with the Liquor Control
Act of the State of Ohio.
(Ord. 53-58. Passed 8-19-58.)
701.99 GENERAL CODE PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with the provisions of this Business
Regulation Code, where no other penalty is prescribed, shall be guilty of a
minor misdemeanor.
 
 
 
CHAPTER 705
Advertising
705.01    Misrepresentation in eyeglass advertising.   
705.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.65
Optometrists - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4725
705.01 MISREPRESENTATION IN EYEGLASS ADVERTISING.
   (a)   No person, partnership, corporation or any agent or employee thereof,
engaged in or connected with the sale of opthalmic lenses, eyeglasses or
eyeglass frames and mountings, shall include in an advertisement by newspaper,
radio, television, display or otherwise, any statement that in any manner
misrepresents any such frames, mountings or other material, prices for the same
or services or credit terms.
   (b)   The provisions of subsection (a) herein shall not apply to any visual
or sound radio broadcasting station or to any publisher or printer of a
newspaper, magazine or other form of printed advertising who broadcasts,
publishes or prints such advertisements in good faith, without knowledge of its
misrepresentative character.
   (c)   No person, partnership, corporation or agent or employee thereof,
engaged in or connected with the sale of ophthalmic lenses, eyeglasses or
eyeglass frames and mountings, shall include in any advertisement by newspaper,
radio, television, display or otherwise, any statement advertising the price of
lenses or of complete eyeglasses, including lenses, either with or without
professional services or credit terms, installment payments or price plan or
the price of any frames or mountings, unless in conjunction therewith the words
"without lenses" appear in such a manner as to be clearly discernible or read
in such a manner as to be clearly understood.
(Ord. 105-69. Passed 10-7-69.)
705.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of Section
705.01 shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not less than three days nor more
than thirty days, or both. Each such advertisement shall constitute a separate
offense.
(Ord. 105-69. Passed 10-7-69.)
CHAPTER 709
Astrology and Fortunetelling
709.01    License required.
709.02    License granting; revocation, fee.
709.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Petty theft - see GEN. OFF.
545.05
Businesses in general - see BUS. REG. Ch.
701
 
709.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall practice astrology, fortunetelling, clairvoyancy or
palmistry within the corporate limits of the City without first having obtained
from the Mayor a license to practice the same.
(Ord. 835. Passed 4-17-35.)
709.02 LICENSE GRANTING; REVOCATION, FEE.
   Upon application, the Mayor shall, at his discretion, grant or refuse the
applicant a license to practice astrology, fortunetelling, clairvoyancy or
palmistry within the corporate limits of the City. Before such license may be
granted, the applicant shall pay a license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). In
the event of any abuse of such license by the applicant or any wrong or injury
committed by the licensee by virtue of such license, the Mayor shall
immediately revoke the license and the license fee shall be forfeited to the
City.
(Ord. 835. Passed 4-17-35.)
709.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or
imprisoned in jail not less than thirty days nor more than three months, or
both.
(Ord. 835. Passed 4-17-35.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 711
Second-Hand Dealers
711.01   Definitions.
711.02   Exceptions.
711.03   Record of acquisition.
711.04   Record of sale.
711.05   Retention of articles by dealer.
711.06   Use of fictitious name or address.
711.07   Purchases prohibited.
711.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Distress merchandise sales - see BUS. REG. Ch.
713
Peddlers and solicitors - see BUS. REG. Ch.
725
 
711.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    Any person, firm or corporation is defined to be a "swap shop" and/or
dealer in second-hand articles for the purposes of this chapter if that person,
firm or corporation engages in the purchase, sale, exchange or receipt of
second-hand articles of whatever nature. This definition specifically includes
any person, firm or corporation that deals in the purchase, sale, exchange or
receipt of used or secondhand articles taken in as trade-ins on a continuing
basis; any person, firm or corporation that deals in the purchase or sale of
pawnbrokers' tickets or other evidence of pledged articles; any person, firm or
corporation that deals in the redemption of pledged articles; and any person,
firm or corporation that deals in the purchase and sale of antiques.
   (b)    "Person" means any individual, partnership, corporation, association
or other organized or united group or entity that includes the personal
responsibility of every officer or director of a corporation.
   (c)    "Second Hand" means that which has been used or which has been
previously traded or sold by a retailer; something which is not new.
   (d)    "Sale or Selling" for purposes of this chapter includes delivery,
barter, exchange, gift or offer thereof.
   (e)    "Antique" means any object, the market value of which is partially or
wholly based upon antiquity, rarity, curiosity, source or authorship.
   (f)    "Second-Hand Major Appliance" means a full-size stove, refrigerator,
washer, dryer or dishwasher.
   (g)    "Fur" means any garment partially or wholly made of any natural
animal fur.
(Ord. 09-40-2011. Passed 9-6-11.)
711.02 EXCEPTIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any person:
   (a)    Conducting a garage sale, lawn sale, yard sale or basement sale at or
within reasonable proximity of his/her garage, lawn, yard or basement;
   (b)    Who engages in the sale of motor vehicles;
   (c)    When transactions of five or fewer compact discs, video game
cartridges and/or video game compact discs, DVD's or books result in store
credit and no money is given for these items;
   (d)    Conducting a charitable rummage sale, book sale and the like, or a
charitable thrift store, where the entire proceeds of such sale or store will
be contributed to a charitable organization;
   (e)    Who deals exclusively in antiques;
   (f)    Who operates a consignment shop;
   (g)    Who operates a junk yard;
   (h)    Who deals exclusively in second-hand furniture;
   (i)    Who deals exclusively in second-hand clothing, except for furs;
   (j)    Conducting an estate sale or auction; or
   (k)    Who deals exclusively in second-hand major appliances.
      (Ord. 09-40-2011. Passed 9-6-11.)
711.03 RECORD OF ACQUISITION.
   (a)    Every dealer in second-hand articles shall keep accurate daily
records of all transactions in a book which shall be legibly written in hand
printing or in ink or typewritten in the English language at the time of
purchase of any second-hand article or articles. These records shall include a
complete description of the article purchased, including all brand names,
dates, serial numbers, model numbers, and words or initials inscribed on the
property; the amount of money given or received for the merchandise; the name,
date of birth, and personal description of the person or persons from whom such
purchase was made, the date and hour of such purchase; and the motor vehicle
operator's license number or state identification card number of the person
from whom the articles were received by the dealer. This statement of
information shall also be signed in the book by the seller of such merchandise.
Further, such book shall be substantially bound, and of a size not less than
six inches in length and width. No entry in such book shall be erased,
obliterated, altered or defaced.
   (b)    Any person prior to purchasing any second-hand articles for the
purpose of resale to the general public, shall examine the seller's driver's
license or identification card issued under Ohio R.C. 4507.50 and 4507.52 and
one additional type of card typically used for identification purposes. (For
the purposes of this section, the purchaser may utilize the written record he
is required to keep where applicable under subsection (a) hereof and add to it
the identification required by this section.)
   (c)    The purchaser shall retain the written record for at least one year
and shall make the record available for inspection by any law enforcement
officer at all reasonable times.
   (d)    Other methods of recording data, keeping records and keeping books,
such as electronic or computerized methods, may be used in lieu of the methods
described in this section, provided written printouts or hard copies of the
required data are readily available in a form approved, in advance, by the
Division of Police, and the seller signs a printout or hard copy of the
required data to certify its accuracy.
   (e)    The requirements of this section shall apply to any transaction
undertaken by a swap shop/second-hand dealer, even if the transaction is to or
from another swap shop/second-hand dealer.
(Ord. 09-40-2011. Passed 9-6-11.)
711.04 RECORD OF SALE.
   At the time of the sale or disposition of any second-hand article, the
dealer in second-hand articles disposing thereof shall enter in his record
book, along with the entry made at the time of acquisition of the second-hand
article, the name, address, telephone number and description of the person to
whom such second-hand article is transferred and shall obtain in ink in his
record book the signature of the person or persons acquiring such second-hand
article. Other methods of recording data as set forth in Section
711.03(d) may also be utilized in lieu of the record book provided the
purchaser signs a printout or hard copy of the required data.
(Ord. 09-40-2011. Passed 9-6-11.)
711.05 RETENTION OF ARTICLES BY DEALER.
   All second-hand articles purchased or received by any dealer in second-hand
articles shall be held by such dealer for a period of 15 days after being
purchased or acquired, unless the disposition of such articles shall be sooner
authorized by the written permission of the Division of Police.
(Ord. 09-40-2011. Passed 9-6-11.)
711.06 USE OF FICTITIOUS NAME OR ADDRESS.
   (a)    No person who sells, exchanges or trades a second-hand article to or
purchases from a swap shop/second-hand dealer shall knowingly give false
information or false identification required under this chapter to the swap
shop/second-hand dealer.
   (b)    No swap shop/second-hand dealer shall purchase, exchange, trade,
receive or sell any second-hand article from a seller who fails to provide
identification or identification required in this chapter.
(Ord. 09-40-2011. Passed 9-6-11.)
711.07 PURCHASES PROHIBITED.
   (a)    No swap shop/second-hand dealer shall knowingly purchase, exchange,
trade, sell or receive any articles from any minor, from any person who at the
time is intoxicated or under the influence of a controlled substance, from any
person who is known or believed by such dealer to be a thief or a receiver of
stolen property, or from any person identified in writing to the dealer by any
law enforcement officer as a known or suspected thief or receiver of stolen
property.
   (b)   No swap shop/second-hand dealer shall purchase, exchange, trade, sell
or receive any articles between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m.
   (c)    Every swap shop/second-hand dealer shall post at the main door of his
place of business the hours or times when the establishment is open for
business. No swap shop/second-hand dealer shall purchase, exchange, trade, sell
or receive secondhand articles or engage in the business of purchasing,
exchanging, trading, selling or receiving second-hand articles during any time
other than any regular business day that the establishment is open for business
as posted.
(Ord. 09-40-2011. Passed 9-6-11.)
711.99 PENALTY.
   (a)    Whoever violates Sections
711.03,
711.04,
711.05,
711.06 or
711.07 shall be guilty of a third degree misdemeanor for the first offense and
shall be guilty of a first degree misdemeanor for subsequent violations
occurring within five years.
   (b)    A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during or
on which the violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 09-40-2011. Passed 9-6-11.)
CHAPTER 713
Distress Merchandise Sales
713.01    Definitions.
713.02    License required.
713.03    License application.
713.04    Bond required.
713.05    Investigation of license application; denial.
713.06    Investigation of records.
713.07    License issuance; conditions.
713.08    License revocation.
713.09    License renewal; fee.
713.10    License fee.
713.11    Exceptions.
713.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Auctions - see Ohio R.C. 1302.41
Door-to-door sales - see Ohio R.C. 1345.21 et seq.
Precious metals dealers, temporary exhibition permit - see Ohio R.C. 4727.04
Casual sales - see Ohio R.C. 5739.01, 5739.02
Sales tax liability for going-out-of-business sales - see Ohio R.C. 5739.14
Businesses in general - see BUS. REG. Ch.
701
 
713.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the
meanings ascribed unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning.
   (a)   "Distress merchandise sale" means any offer to sell to the public, or
actual sale to the public, of goods, wares or merchandise on the implied or
direct representation that such sale is in anticipation of the termination of a
business at its present location or that the sale is being held other than in
the ordinary course of business. Without limiting the generality of the above,
distress merchandise sales shall include any sale advertised either
specifically or in substance to be a "fire sale", "smoke and water damage
sale", "adjustment sale", "creditor's sale", "trustee's sale", "bankrupt sale",
"save us from bankruptcy sale", "insolvent sale", "insurance salvage sale",
"mortgage sale", "assignee's sale", "adjuster's sale", "must vacate sale",
"quitting business sale", "receiver's sale", "loss of lease sale", "forced out
of business sale", or "removal sale."
   (b)   "Person" means any individual, partnership, association, firm or
corporation.
(Ord. 59-63. Passed 7-2-63.)
713.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall advertise or conduct a distress merchandise sale without
first having obtained a license to do so in accordance with the provisions of
this chapter.
(Ord. 59-63. Passed 7-2-63.)
713.03 LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Any person desiring to conduct a distress merchandise sale shall make
written application to the Mayor at least five days prior to the date on which
the sale is to commence, on forms furnished by the Mayor and verified by the
applicant before a person authorized to administer oaths. In cases where, due
to circumstances beyond the control of the applicant other than economic
reverses, application cannot be made five days prior to the commencement of the
sale, the Mayor shall waive the five-day requirement. Each application shall
contain the following information and such other information the Mayor may deem
necessary:
   (a)   The name and address of the owner of the goods, wares or merchandise
to be sold.
   (b)   A description of the place where such sale is to be held.
   (c)   The nature of the occupancy of the place where such sale is to be
held, whether by lease or otherwise, and the effective date of the termination
of such occupancy.
   (d)   A full and complete statement of the facts regarding the distress
merchandise sale, including the reason why such sale is being conducted, the
manner in which such sale will be conducted and the commencement and
termination date of such sale.
   (e)   A complete and detailed inventory of the goods, wares and merchandise
to be offered at such sale as disclosed by the applicant's records, or a
statement of both the cost and retail value of the inventory of goods, wares
and merchandise to be offered at such sale, based on the physical inventory
used for applicant's most recent Federal income tax return adjusted for sales,
purchases and mark-downs. Adjustments for sales, purchases and mark-downs shall
be shown on a monthly basis to date of application. In addition, there shall be
shown as separate items in either form of inventory, the retail value of all
goods, wares and merchandise the applicant has on consignment which will be
offered for sale and the cost and retail value of all goods, wares and
merchandise on back order.
   The filing of an application for a license, the contents of such application
and the issuance of a license shall be confidential information and no
disclosure thereof shall be made except such as may be necessary in the
administration of the provisions of this chapter. However, any disclosure may
be made with the consent of the applicant, and the filing of an application and
the issuance of a license shall not be considered confidential after public
notice has been given of the proposed sale. Disclosures made contrary to the
provisions of this subsection shall be subject to the penalty provided in
Section
713.99.
(Ord. 59-63. Passed 7-2-63.)
713.04 BOND REQUIRED.
   No license shall be issued for a distress merchandise sale unless there is
filed with the Mayor a bond conditioned upon the faithful observance of all the
provisions of this chapter and the indemnifying of any purchaser at such sale
who suffers any loss by reason of any misrepresentation made in connection with
the sale, and authorizing actions thereunder by the City for the violation of
any provision of this chapter, and by any purchaser at the sale for damage or
loss suffered by him by reason of any misrepresentation made in connection with
the sale. The amount of such bond shall be determined as follows: ten percent
(10%) of the first one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) of the inventory
cost of all the goods, wares and merchandise to be offered at the sale, five
percent (5%) on the next four hundred dollars ($400.00) and two percent (2%) on
the balance. The bond shall be approved as to form by the Solicitor and as to
sufficiency by the Auditor.
(Ord. 59-63. Passed 7-2-63.)
713.05 INVESTIGATION OF LICENSE APPLICATION; DENIAL.
   Upon receipt of an application, the Mayor shall cause such investigation as
he deems necessary to be made of the facts contained therein. No license shall
be issued if any one or more of the following facts or circumstances are bound
to exist:
   (a)   That the applicant was granted more than one license hereunder for a
going-out-of- business sale within two years preceding the date of the filing
of the application.
   (b)   The the applicant has heretofore been convicted of a violation of this
chapter or has had a license issued to him pursuant to this chapter revoked
within a five-year period immediately preceding the date of the filing of the
application.
   (c)   That the inventory includes goods, wares, or merchandise purchased by
the applicant or added to his stock in contemplation of such sale and for the
purpose of selling the same at such sale. Any unusual addition to the stock of
such goods, wares and merchandise made within sixty days prior to the filing of
such application shall be prima-facie evidence that such addition was made in
contemplation of such sale and for the purpose of selling the same at such
sale.
   (d)   That the applicant, in the ticketing of the goods, wares and
merchandise to be offered at the sale, has misrepresented the original retail
price or value thereof.
   (e)   That any representation made in the application is false.
(Ord. 59-63. Passed 7-2-63.)
713.06 INVESTIGATION OF RECORDS.
   The Mayor shall, from time to time, enter into contracts with competent,
qualified persons for the examination of the inventories and records of
applicants for licenses. Such persons shall work under the direction and
control of the Mayor and shall make such examinations of records and
inventories as are specified by the Mayor and authorized by this chapter. All
information obtained by such persons or any City employees or officials through
applications or examinations made, pursuant to this chapter, shall be
confidential and no person shall make any disclosure thereof, except where such
disclosure is necessary in the administration of the provisions of this
chapter.
(Ord. 59-63. Passed 7-2-63.)
713.07 LICENSE ISSUANCE; CONDITIONS.
   When it appears to the Mayor that all the statements in the application are
true and that the proposed sale is of the character represented therein, that
the application is in full compliance with the terms and conditions of this
chapter, and that the required license fee has been paid and the required bond
filed, the Mayor shall issue a license to the applicant authorizing the
applicant to advertise and conduct the sale as described in the application,
subject to the following conditions:
   (a)   The sale shall be held at the place named in the application and by
the particular licensee for a period of not more than thirty consecutive
calendar days, Sundays and legal holidays excluded, next following the date
specified in the license.
   (b)   Only the goods, wares and merchandise included in the inventory
attached to the application shall be sold at the sale.
   (c)   Upon the commencement of the sale and for its duration, the license
issued hereunder shall be prominently displayed in the place of sale by the
licensee.
   (d)   The licensee shall keep suitable books during the sale, at the
location at which the sale is conducted, in which shall be made daily entries
showing:
      (1)   The dollar amount of retail sales.
      (2)   The dollar amount of mark-downs. Without limiting the meaning of
the term "mark-down", the difference between the retail and wholesale price of
goods wholesaled by the licensee shall be a mark-down.
      (3)   The dollar amount, both retail and cost price, of goods of back
order received.
      (4)   The dollar amount of wholesale sales.
Copies of such daily entries shall be sent to the Mayor weekly and all books of
the licensee shall be open for inspection by the Mayor or his duly authorized
representatives during business hours.
(Ord. 59-63. Passed 7-2-63.)
713.08 LICENSE REVOCATION.
   The Mayor shall revoke any license issued pursuant to the provisions of this
chapter if he finds that the licensee has:
   (a)   Violated the provisions of this chapter.
   (b)   Made any material misstatement in his application.
   (c)   Failed to include in the inventory required by the provisions of this
chapter all the goods, wares and merchandise being offered for sale.
   (d)   Offered or permitted to be offered at the sale any goods, wares or
merchandise not included in the inventory attached to the application.
   (e)   Failed to keep suitable records of the sale.
   (f)   Made or permitted to be made any false or misleading statements or
representations in advertising the sale or in displaying, ticketing or pricing
goods, wares or merchandise offered for sale.
(Ord. 59-63. Passed 7-2-63.)
713.09 LICENSE RENEWAL; FEE.
   The Mayor shall, upon application therefor, renew a license issued under the
provisions of this chapter for one or more periods of thirty days each, Sundays
and legal holidays excluded, if the licensee has not sold all the goods listed
on the inventory submitted with the original application. Such fact shall be
sworn to, by the applicant, in the appropriate place on the application for
renewal of the license. Only such goods as were listed on the original
inventory filed with the application and not previously sold, may be sold
during the renewal period. The fee for the renewal of a license shall be ten
dollars ($10.00).
(Ord. 59-63. Passed 7-2-63.)
713.10 LICENSE FEE.
   The fee for licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall be twenty-five
dollars ($25.00) or one fourth of one percent (.25%) of the cost inventory
value of the goods, wares and merchandise to be sold at the sale, whichever is
the greater amount.
(Ord. 59-63. Passed 7-2-63.)
713.11 EXCEPTIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any sale conducted by a
public officer as part of his official duties or to any sale, an accounting of
which must be made to a court of law, or to any sale conducted pursuant to an
order of a court of law.
(Ord. 59-63. Passed 7-2-63.)
713.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
less than twenty- five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars
($100.00) or imprisoned not more than thirty days, or both. Each day's
violation shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 59-63. Passed 7-2-63.)
CHAPTER 717
Food and Food Handlers
   EDITOR'S NOTE: Provisions concerning food and food handlers are enforced by
the Pickaway County Board of Health. There are no sections in Chapter
717. This chapter has been established to provide a place for cross references
and for future legislation.
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to inspect food products - see Ohio R.C. 715.46
Food service operations - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 3732
Adulterating of or furnishing adulterated food or confection - see GEN. OFF.
537.13
CHAPTER 718
Food Trucks
718.01   Definition.
718.02   Food truck license submittal requirements.
718.03   Food truck requirements.
718.04   Fee required.
718.01 DEFINITION.
   “FOOD TRUCK/TRAILER (Food Truck)” means a vehicle from which food for human
consumption is sold and dispensed. Said food can be prepackaged or prepared
within the vehicle. Such vehicle may be self-propelled or towed by another
vehicle and must be licensed in the state of Ohio.
(Ord. 09-68-2022. Passed 2-20-22.)
718.02 FOOD TRUCK LICENSE SUBMITTAL REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Any person or people desiring to operate a Food Truck within the City
of Circleville Limits must receive a Food Truck License prior to operations.
The applicant for a Food Truck license is required to obtain the following in
order to receive a license:
      (1)   A valid state vehicle registration information for the unit
proposed to be permitted for food service operation.
      (2)   A current and valid license issued by the applicable department of
health pursuant to the Ohio Revised Code to conduct retail food operations.
      (3)   Ohio Department of Taxation Transient Vendor’s License, if required
by State law.
      (4)   Liability and property damage insurance. Limits of such coverage
shall not be less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000) for Food Carts
and not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000) for Food Trucks/Trailers.
      (5)   Inspection and approval of all fire extinguishers by the
Circleville Fire Department.
      (6)   Applicable fee in accordance with Section
718.04.
         (Ord. 09-68-2022. Passed 9-20-22.)
718.03 FOOD TRUCK REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   An applicant must be current and compliant in the payment of all taxes
on payroll and net profits. If the applicant is not current and compliant in
the payment of any taxes on payroll and net profits, proof that the applicant
has entered into an agreement to pay any delinquency and is abiding by the
terms of the agreement is required at the time this application is submitted.
   (b)   Any Food Truck that is operating within the City of Circleville shall
have readily available within the Food Truck an operating fire extinguisher
that is inspected and approved prior to the issuance of a Permit. Additionally,
fire extinguishers shall be regularly inspected by the Fire Marshal in
accordance with the Ohio Fire Code. Any Food Truck that contains a Fryer shall
maintain a Class K fire Extinguisher. All other Food Trucks shall maintain a
Class A-B-C fire extinguisher.
   (c)   Upon the issuance of an Operating Permit, any Food Truck desiring to
operate within the City of Circleville shall obtain one of the following:
Either a) a Zoning Permit if operating on private property or b) a Right-of-Way
permit if operating on public property.
      (1)   Zoning permits are issued per Section
1145.11 of the City of Circleville Zoning Code.
      (2)   Right-of-Way permits may not be issued for more than three eight-
hour periods within a seven consecutive day period.
      (3)   No Food Truck shall obtain a Right-of-Way license of Zoning Permit
prior to receiving an Operating Permit from the City of Circleville.
   (d)   If the requirements of Section
718.02 and
718.03(a) - (c) are met, then the Service Director or designee shall issue the
Food Truck License.
(Ord. 09-68-2022. Passed 9-20-22.)
718.04 FEE REQUIRED.
   (a)   The following fees shall apply for a Food Truck License.
          Monthly License: $10.00
          Semi-Annual License: $20.00
          Yearly License: $30.00
          Yearly License Renewal: $10.00
   (b)   Licenses will be valid for the period stated on the License, and in
accordance with the above fee schedule.
(Ord. 09-68-2022. Passed 9-20-22.)
CHAPTER 721
Junkyards
721.01    Definitions.
721.02    License required; compliance with provisions.
721.03    Fence required; license fee; revocation.   
721.04    License application.
721.05    Fence maintenance.
721.06    Inspections.
721.07    Court injunction for violation.
721.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61
Secondhand dealers - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4737
Record of transaction required - see Ohio R.C. 4737.01, 4737.04
State licensing and required fencing of junkyards outside a municipality - see
Ohio R.C. 4737.05 et seq.
Storage of junk - see GEN. OFF.
521.12
721.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the following
definitions:
   (a)   "Junk" means old or scrap copper, brass, rope, rags, batteries, paper,
rubber, junked, dismantled or wrecked automobiles or parts thereof, iron, steel
and other old or scrap ferrous or nonferrous materials which are not held for
sale for remelting purposes by an establishment having facilites for processing
such materials.
   (b)   "Junkyard" means an establishment or place of business, other than an
establishment having facilities for processing iron, steel or nonferrous scrap
and whose principal product is scrap-iron or steel or nonferrous scrap for sale
or remelting purposes, which is maintained or operated for the purpose of
storing, keeping, buying or selling junk or for the maintenance or operation of
an automobile graveyard, except an establishment or place where automobiles,
wrecked or otherwise, are held or impounded for a period not exceeding ninety
days exclusively for storage, repair or resale without alteration.
   (c)   "Fence" means an enclosure at least six feet in height, constructed of
nontransparent material, and maintained so as to obscure the junk in the
enclosure from the ordinary view of persons passing upon the State, City and
other streets and public thoroughfares of the City.
(Ord. 20-64. Passed 4-7-64.)
721.02 LICENSE REQUIRED; COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS.
   No person shall operate or maintain a junkyard within the City unless he has
first obtained a license issued under the provisions of this chapter. No
licensee shall operate or maintain a junkyard in violation of the provisions of
this chapter.
(Ord. 20-64. Passed 4-7-64.)
721.03 FENCE REQUIRED; LICENSE FEE; REVOCATION.
   No person shall operate and maintain a junkyard within the Municipality
without first obtaining a license to do so from the Auditor of the City. Any
person operating a junkyard prior to the effective date of the provisions of
this chapter is entitled to be issued a license or a renewal thereof upon
payment of the fee provided for in this section. Any person operating or
maintaining a junkyard within 1,000 feet of a State highway or any other public
thoroughfare prior to the effective date of this chapter, shall have six months
after this chapter becomes effective to erect the required fence if such
junkyard is not obscured by natural objects. If, after the effective date of
this chapter, a junkyard is established within 1,000 feet of a State highway
located within the City or any other public thoroughfare, it must be so located
that the view thereof from such road shall be obscured by natural objects or a
fence. If the yard is so obscured, the person operating or maintaining it shall
be entitled to a license.
   The fee for a license issued under this section is twenty-five dollars
($25.00). All licenses issued hereunder shall expire on January 1, following
the date of issuance. A license may be renewed from year to year upon paying
the Auditor of the City the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) for each such renewal.
All licenses issued hereunder shall be signed by the Mayor.
   All fees paid under this section shall be for the use of the City and shall
be credited to the General Revenue Fund of the City.
   Any license or renewal thereof issued under this section may be revoked by
the Auditor after both reasonable notice and the opportunity to be heard for
any violation of any provision of this chapter by the licensee or by any of his
officers, agents or employees. Whenever a license has been revoked under this
section the Auditor shall not issue another license to such licensee, to the
husband or wife of such licensee, or to any partnership or corporation of which
the licensee is an officer or member until the expiration of at least one year
from the date of the revocation of such license.
(Ord. 20-64. Passed 4-7-64.)
721.04 LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Application for a license to operate and maintain a junkyard or for a
renewal thereof shall be made in writing accompanied by the proper fee, to the
Auditor, setting forth the name and address of the applicant, the location of
the junkyard, and stating if the applicant is a corporation, partnership or
association and the names and addresses of each member. If the applicant is a
corporation, the date and place of incorporation and the names and addresses of
its officer and directors and such other reasonable information as the Auditor
deems necessary shall be required. The application shall be signed and sworn to
by the applicant.
(Ord. 20-64. Passed 4-7-64.)
721.05 FENCE MAINTENANCE.
   Any fence constructed under the provisions of this chapter shall be neatly
constructed, nontransparent, and kept in good order and repair. No
advertisement shall be permitted thereon other than the name of the person
under whose name the license has been issued and the nature of the business
conducted therein.
(Ord. 20-64. Passed 4-7-64.)
721.06 INSPECTIONS.
   Every six months, the Public Safety Director shall inspect every junkyard
that is located within the City for which a license has been issued to obtain
information with regard as to whether the licensee's business is being
conducted in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The Public Safety
Director shall submit a written report of each such examination to the Auditor.
   The Public Safety Director shall, for the purpose of this examination, have
free access to the grounds and buildings used in the conduct of the junkyard
business by the licensee.
   Such inspections may be made at any time, at the option of the Public Safety
Director, during the regular work hours of the licensee or within the hours of
8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday.
(Ord. 20-64. Passed 4-7-64.)
721.07 COURT INJUNCTION FOR VIOLATION.
   Whenever the Director of Law of the City is of the opinion that a junkyard
is being operated or maintained in violation of any of the provisions of this
chapter, he may apply, in the name of the City, to a court of competent
jurisdiction, alleging the violation complained of and praying for an
injunction or other proper relief. In such case, the court may order such
junkyard abated as a nuisance or make such other order as may be proper. An
action brought under this section shall not be deemed to be a bar to a
prosecution under Section
721.99.
(Ord. 20-64. Passed 4-7-64.)
721.99  PENALTY.
   For any section in which a penalty has not been specified, the penalty shall
be imposed pursuant to Section
701.99 of these Codified Ordinances.
CHAPTER 725
Peddlers, Solicitors and Canvassers
725.01   Definitions.
725.02   Peddling, soliciting or canvassing.
725.03   Organizational liability.
725.04   Display of registration card.
725.05   Sales on public ground.
725.06   Prosecution for violation.
725.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to inspect food products - see Ohio R.C. 715.46
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61 et seq.
      Home solicitation sales - see Ohio R.C. 1345.21 et seq.
      Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R. C. Ch. 1716
      Littering - see GEN. OFF.
521.08
      Trespassing - see GEN. OFF.
541.05
      Noise control - see BUS. REG. Ch.
745
725.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)    "Person" means individuals, associations of individuals,
partnerships, corporations, societies and trusts.
   (b)    "Peddler" means any person who travels door to door either by foot,
automobile, truck, or any other type of conveyance and calls upon private
residents, including any house, apartment or other dwelling within the City,
taking or attempting to take orders for profit for the sale of goods, wares,
and merchandise or personal property of any nature whatsoever for immediate or
future delivery or for services to be furnished and/or performed immediately or
in the future.
   (c)    "Solicitor" means any person who seeks to obtain funds for any cause
whatsoever by traveling door to door either by foot, automobile, truck, or any
type of conveyance and calling upon private residences including any house,
apartment or other dwelling with the City.
   (d)    "Canvasser" means any person who obtains or influences the opinions
of the residents of the City by traveling door to door either by foot,
automobile, truck or any other type of conveyance and calling upon private
residences including any house, apartment or other dwelling in the City, but
does not seek to obtain funds for any cause whatsoever.
   (e)    "Charitable" means and includes the words patriotic, philanthropic,
social service, welfare, athletic, benevolent, educational, civic, fraternal,
veterans, medical and social research, either actual or purported, or other
non-profit organization.
   (f)    "Religious" and "religion" as used herein shall not include the word
charitable, but shall be given their commonly accepted definitions.
   (g)    "Religious Organization" means any church, body of communicants or
group that is not organized or operated for profit that gathers in common
membership for regular worship and religious observance.
   (h)    "Personal Services" as used herein means any business enterprise with
the primary purpose of providing a service based on intellectual or manual
personal labor or efforts of an individual rather than a saleable product of
his or her skills.
      (Ord. 11-63-16. Passed 11-15-16.)
725.02 PEDDLING, SOLICITING OR CANVASSING.
   (a)    Registration Required. No peddler or solicitor shall peddle or
solicit within the City unless he or she is the holder of a valid registration
issued pursuant to this chapter. Canvassers do not need to register but must
abide by relevant sections of this chapter.
   (b)    Registration Application: Contents. Application for a registration as
a solicitor or as a peddler shall be made upon a form provided by the Director
of Public Safety or his designee. Each application shall contain among other
information:
      (1)    The name, address and telephone number of the applicant;
      (2)    The name, address, and telephone number of his or her employers,
if any;
      (3)    The nature of the goods or services for which he or she will take
orders or to be offered for sale;
      (4)    Proof of motor vehicle insurance;
      (5)    A valid operator's license;
      (6)    The proposed method of operation in the City;
      (7)    A written commitment that such person(s) shall comply with Chapter
725 of the Codified Ordinances; and
      (8)    Such other information as the Director of Public Safety or his
designee may require.
   (c)    Criminal Background Checks.
      (1)    Required. All peddlers and solicitors not exempt under this
chapter are required to provide a Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Federal
Bureau of Investigation criminal background check completed that is no more
than 30 days old. Said background check must be presented at the time a
registration application is completed and obtained from an authorized agency.
      
   (d)    Registration prohibition.
      (1)    No person shall be issued a registration who has been convicted
of:
         A.    Any felony; or
         B.    Any misdemeanors involving false statements, dishonesty, theft,
offenses of violence, offenses against juveniles, or violations of Ohio Revised
Code Chapter 2907, or
         C.   Any violation of this chapter.
   (e)    Registration Expiration. All registrations issued under this chapter
shall be valid
for not more than one year from date of issue or as otherwise provided for by
the Director of Public Safety or his designee.
   (f)    Registration Exceptions.  The provisions of Sections
725.02 shall not apply to the following:
      (1)   Any person soliciting or peddling anything which such person has
personally manufactured or produced. This exemption shall apply only to natural
persons.
      (2)   Any farmer, poultryman or horticulturist soliciting or peddling his
own produce. This exemption shall apply only to natural persons and shall not
apply to farms, poultrymen or horticulturists who buy goods for resale, as well
as selling their own produce.
      (3)   Any person soliciting for personal services to be performed by the
person so soliciting. This exemption shall apply only to natural persons.
      (4)    Any natural person soliciting or peddling for or selling tickets
for any religious, civic, charitable, school, educational or veteran's
organization.
      (5)    Any peddling of or soliciting for the sale of religious or
education publications and books.
   (g)    Registration Revocation.
      (1)    Any registration issued hereunder shall be revoked by the Director
of Public Safety or his designee if the holder thereof is convicted of a
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, has made a false material
statement in the application, or is found to be conducting the soliciting or
peddling in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of
the peace or to be a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the
people of the City.
      (2)    Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be
given by the Director of Public Safety or his designee to the holder of the
registration in person or by certified U.S. mail addressed to his or her
residence address as set forth in the application. Immediately upon the giving
of such notice the registration shall become null and void.
   (h)    Fraudulent Solicitations Prohibited.
      (1)    No solicitor or peddler shall make or perpetrate any misstatement,
deception, or fraud in connection with any solicitation of any contribution for
any charitable purpose.
      (2)    No person having entered into an agreement to conduct any
solicitation on behalf of any person or any charitable purpose shall fail to
remit or pay to the party entitled thereto the proceeds of such solicitation in
accordance with the true terms of the agreement.
   (i)   Fee.
      (1)    No person shall act as a peddler or solicitor without the
invitation or previous consent of the owner( s) or occupant( s) without first
having secured from the Director of Public Safety or his designee a
registration therefor. The fee for each registration shall be as follows:
         A.    For one day: $25.00.
         B.    For one week: $50.00.
         C.    For one year: $200.00
      (2)    All fees collected shall be paid into the General Fund.
      (3)    Fee exemption. Individuals or corporations soliciting or peddling
on behalf of an educational, religious, civic or charitable organization or as
otherwise set forth in Section
 725.02(g) shall not be required to pay registration fees.
   
   (j)    Nontransferable. Once issued a registration may be used only in
conformity with the laws of the City and the State of Ohio and may not be
assigned or transferred.
   (k)   Restrictions; Hours; Conduct.  Every person to whom a registration to
peddle or solicit is issued and every canvasser shall be governed by the
following rules and regulations:
      (1)    No person subject to the provisions of this chapter shall peddle,
solicit, or canvass except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. or one-
half hour after sunset whichever is later.
      (2)    No peddler, solicitor or canvasser shall enter or attempt to enter
a residence, house, apartment or other dwelling in the City without an express
invitation from an adult occupant of the residence, house, apartment or other
dwelling.
      (3)    No peddler or solicitor shall engage in any peddling or
solicitation other than that specified in the registration application.
      (4)    No peddler, solicitor or canvasser shall by any device make
unlawful noises, nor shall any peddler, solicitor or canvasser remain at the
residence, house, apartment or other dwelling in the City without the consent
of any adult occupant of the residence, house, apartment or other dwelling in
the City.
   (l)    Resident Prohibition by Notice. Notwithstanding any other provision
of this chapter, no peddler, solicitor, or canvasser, while peddling,
soliciting or canvassing, shall call upon, knock at the door or ring the door
bell of any residence, house, apartment or other dwelling in the City upon
which there is posted at the entrance a notice which reads: "No Peddlers,
Solicitors or Canvassers Allowed", or words of similar import, which clearly
prohibits peddlers, solicitors and canvassers on the premises, unless such
peddler, solicitor or canvasser has previously been invited upon the premises
by the owner, lessee or an adult occupant thereof.
   (m)    Appeals. Any registrant or applicant may appeal his/her revocation or
denial to the City Council. The Appeal application shall set forth the basis
for the appeal and any grounds for a reversal of the decision of the Director
of Public Safety. Said appeal shall be heard within 30 days and shall be filed
with City Council within 15 days of the registrant or applicant receiving
notice of such revocation or denial. Notice of the hearing on such appeal shall
be given in writing by the Clerk stating the grounds of the appeal and the time
and place of hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage pre-paid, to the
applicant or registrant at the address given on the application for the
registration or as stated in the appeal, at least 10 days prior to the date set
for the hearing. Upon hearing, Council shall make a finding in writing within
45 days of the hearing and shall mail said finding to the applicant or
registrant at the address provided on the application or on the appeal. (Ord.
11-63-16. Passed 11-15-16.)
725.03 ORGANIZATIONAL LIABILITY.
   The organization sponsoring or employing individuals violating any of the
provisions of Chapter
725 may be prosecuted and held liable for the criminal penalties contained
herein.
(Ord. 11-63-16. Passed 11-15-16.)
725.04 DISPLAY OF REGISTRATION CARD.
   Any peddler or solicitor shall, at all times while soliciting or peddling,
have his registration in his/her immediate possession. Upon request of any
resident, police officer or City official, a solicitor or peddler shall present
said registration card for further inspection.
(Ord. 11-63-16. Passed 11-15-16.)
725.05 SALES ON PUBLIC GROUND.
   No person shall sell or distribute on streets, alleys, parks or other public
grounds of the City any goods, wares, merchandise, food products or other
articles except for the following:
   (a)    A person selling by sample only;
   (b)    A farmer, poultryman or horticulturist selling or soliciting his own
agricultural products or produce. This exception shall apply only to natural
persons and shall not apply to farmers, poultrymen, or horticulturists who buy
goods for resale, as well as selling their own produce or products;
   (c)    A person selling or distributing anything which such person has
personally manufactured or produced, except that this exemption shall apply
only to natural persons;
   (d)    A person selling or distributing any products, goods, wares,
merchandise, food or other articles on behalf of any religious, civic,
charitable, school, educational, athletic, veterans' organization, or other
non-profit organization, subject to any restrictions set forth in paragraph (e)
of this section relating to sales during street fairs/festivals within the
City;
   (e)    A person selling goods, wares, merchandise, food, products or other
articles on public streets and sidewalks of the City during a street fair/
festival approved by City Council, within the areas designated for the street
fair/festival by City Council and who is otherwise in compliance with all the
terms, conditions and restrictions set forth in the rules and regulations for
street fairs/festivals established by City Council; or
   (f)    A person selling or distributing articles or products in the City as
part of a retail sales route by which he or she regularly sells articles or
products in the City not less frequently than one day in every six week period.
      (Ord. 11-63-16. Passed 11-15-16.)
725.06  PROSECUTION FOR VIOLATION.
   Conviction and punishment of any person for peddling or soliciting without a
registration shall not excuse or exempt such person from the payment of any
registration fee due or unpaid at the time of such conviction and nothing in
this chapter shall prevent criminal prosecution for any violations of any
provision of this chapter.
(Ord. 11-63-16. Passed 11-15-16.)
725.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor and, in addition, may have his or her registration revoked by the
Director of Public Safety or his designee. A second offense shall be enhanced
to a misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
(Ord. 11-63-16. Passed 11-15-16.)
CHAPTER 729
Private Haulers
   EDITOR'S NOTE: Chapter
729 was repealed as part of the 1982 updating and revision of the Codified
Ordinances.
CHAPTER 733
Taxicabs
733.01    Definitions.
733.02    Taxicab Board.
733.03    Operating license required, expiration, fee.
733.04   License application.
733.05   License issuance or denial; assessment of public interest.
733.06   Insurance required; approval.
733.07   Bond in lieu of insurance.
733.08   Soliciting patronage and cruising restrictions.
733.09   Rate of schedules on file.
733.10   Safety equipment requirements.
733.11   License suspension or revocation; taxicab inspection.
733.12   Railroad crossings.
733.13   Establishment of taxicab stands.
733.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.22, 715.66
Power to establish stands and fix rates - see Ohio R.C. 715.25
Operation and equipment - see TRAF. Ch.
331
 
733.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following words shall have the
following meanings:
   (a)   “Board” means the Taxicab Board.
   (b)   “Taxicab” means any vehicle propelled by power other than muscular,
except omnibusses, funeral cars and public busses, kept or operated for hire
for any consideration. It does not include any automobile leased or rented for
private use without the services of a chauffeur or driver.
      (Ord. 10-59-2002. Passed 10-1-02.)
733.02 TAXICAB BOARD.
   A Taxicab Board, consisting of the Mayor, the Police Chief and the Public
Safety Director, is hereby created for the purpose of determining the interests
of the public in the issuing of Taxicab Operating Licenses in the City, for the
issuance of such licenses and other licenses as hereinafter provided and for
the regulation of taxicabs. The Taxicab Board shall meet, at such times and at
such places as may be designated by the Chairman of the Board, to consider
applications for Taxicab Operating Licenses and to transact such other and
further business with which it may be charged by this chapter. However, the
Chairman of the Board shall, within ten days after any application for a
Taxicab Operating License has been filed with the Secretary of the Board, call
a meeting of the Board for the purpose of considering such application. Such
hearing shall be held within twenty days from the filing of the application and
completion of vehicle inspections. Vehicle inspections must be completed within
ten days of application and an Officer of the Police Department, to be
determined by the Chief of Police, will do said inspections. Each applicant
shall be notified of the time and place of the hearing of his application for
Taxicab Operating License by letter from the Secretary of the Taxicab Board,
addressed to the address given in the application and mailed at least three
days prior to the hearing or it may be hand delivered within two days of said
hearing. Two members of the Board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction
of business and two votes shall be necessary to approve the application. The
Board is authorized and empowered to establish and adopt such rules and
regulations governing its procedure and duties as are reasonable, necessary and
not inconsistent with the terms of this chapter. The Mayor shall act as
Chairman of Board and the Police Chief as Secretary. The Secretary shall keep a
record of all proceedings of the Board.
(Ord. 10-59-2002. Passed 10-1-02.)
733.03 OPERATING LICENSE REQUIRED, EXPIRATION, FEE.
   No taxicab shall operate unless a Taxicab Operating License therefor has
been issued to the owner and is in force. Every license shall expire on
December 31, of the year for which it is issued. The annual fee shall be
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and shall be in addition to the fee required under
the laws of the State on all motor vehicles. A copy of said Taxicab Operating
License must be displayed in the vehicle or available for review upon request
from passengers or Law Enforcement Official.
(Ord. 10-59-2002. Passed 10-1-02.)
733.04 LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Applications for Taxicab Operating Licenses shall be made to the Secretary
of the Taxicab Board upon blanks provided by the Secretary. The forms shall
require the name and address of the applicant, the trade name under which he
does business, the class of vehicle for which the Taxicab Operating License is
desired, the seating capacity, design, color scheme, lettering and marks to be
used on such vehicle and any other information required by the Secretary,
including, for the particular vehicle to be given a Taxicab Operating License,
the make, Ohio State License Plate number, name and address of the person from
whom the vehicle was purchased, together with a copy of the bill of sale or
certificate of title and any other information required by the Secretary.
(Ord. 10-59-2002. Passed 10-1-02.)
733.05 LICENSE ISSUANCE OR DENIAL; ASSESSMENT OF PUBLIC INTEREST.
   (a)   The Taxicab Board shall investigate and hold a hearing upon each
application for a Taxicab Operating License and if the Board finds from such
investigation and hearing that the public interest justifies the operation of
the vehicle for which a Taxicab Operating License is desired, that the
applicant is the owner of the vehicle for which a Taxicab Operating License is
desired, that such vehicle is a safe and fit conveyance for a taxicab service
and that it complies with all requirements of this chapter, the Board shall
authorize the issuance of a Taxicab Operating License to the applicant, upon
payment of the proper Taxicab Operating License fee and the furnishing of the
bond or insurance required. The decision of the Board shall be final. Such
Taxicab Operating License shall be in the form provided by the Board, shall be
issued by the Secretary of the Board when authorized by the Board and shall
bear the name of the owner to whom such license shall be issued. All Taxicab
Operating Licenses shall be signed by the Mayor.
   (b)   If the Board finds from such investigation and hearing that the public
interest does not justify the operation of the vehicle for which a Taxicab
Operating License is desired, that the applicant is not the owner of the
vehicle for which a Taxicab Operating License is desired, that such vehicle is
not a safe and fit conveyance for taxicab service or that it does not comply
with all the requirements of this chapter, it shall forthwith notify the
applicant of its findings and refuse to issue the Taxicab Operating License.
The decision of the Board is final.
   (c)   All taxicabs that were given a Taxicab Operating License or that were
licensed at the date of passage of this chapter shall continue to hold such
licenses without an assessment of public interest by the Taxicab Board,
provided all other requirements of this section are complied with.
(Ord. 10-59-2002. Passed 10-1-02.)
733.06  INSURANCE REQUIRED; APPROVAL.
   (a)   No license to operate any taxicab shall be issued and no person shall
operate or permit the operation of any such taxicab unless the owner of the
same shall deposit with the Secretary of the Taxicab Board a policy of an
insurance company, duly licensed to transact such business in the State,
insuring the owner of such taxicab and also any person operating the same in
the City against loss from any legal liability for property damage resulting
from the use of such taxicab, in an amount not less than ten thousand dollars
($10,000) for each taxicab, and also insuring the owner and operator of such
taxicab against any loss from legal liability for damages caused by personal
injuries, including death resulting from the use of such taxicab, in an amount
not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) for the injury or death
of one person and not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000) for
injuries or death to more than one person caused by any one accident, for each
taxicab. Such insurance must be kept in full force and effect during the period
for which the Taxicab Operating License is issued.
   (b)   Any such insurance policy shall be subject to the approval of the City
Law Director as to its form and compliance with this chapter.
(Ord. 10-59-2002. Passed 10-1-02.)
733.07 BOND IN LIEU OF INSURANCE.
   In lieu of the insurance policies herein provided for, the applicant may
furnish a bond executed by a surety company authorized to do business in the
State, or by one or more personal sureties, approved as to sufficiency by the
Taxicab Board and as to form and legality by the City Law Director, holding and
binding the principal and sureties to the same liability and in accordance with
the same terms as the insurance policies provided for in Section
737.06.
(Ord. 10-59-2002. Passed 10-1-02.)
733.08 SOLICITING PATRONAGE AND CRUISING RESTRICTIONS.
   (a)   No taxicab driver shall solicit patronage while on the streets, except
in front of the taxicab stands as established in Section
733.13.
   (b)   No driver of any taxicab shall cruise such taxicab on the streets.
(Ord. 10-59-2002. Passed 10-1-02.)
733.09  RATE OF SCHEDULES ON FILE.
   (a)   Every owner of one or more taxicabs shall maintain on file with the
Secretary of the Taxicab Board the complete schedule of rates offered and used
by such taxicabs. Such schedule shall set forth in detail the amounts charged
by each taxicab for service under a taxi metered rate, if a taximeter is used,
and the hourly rate or trip rate, if an hourly or trip rate is used. Such rates
shall be effective upon approval by and endorsement of the Board.
   (b)   All schedules of rates of fare on file with the Secretary of the Board
shall be open to public inspection.
   (c)   No driver or any other person in control of a taxicab shall operate
such taxicab except in accordance with the schedule of rates filed as herein
provided.
(Ord. 10-59-2002. Passed 10-1-02.)
733.10  SAFETY EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS.
   Every taxicab shall be kept in a safe and sanitary operating condition and
shall at all times have the following equipment:
   (a)   A light within the passenger compartment capable of being lighted or
extinguished by the passengers.
      (1)   This may be waived if taxicab is licensed for daylight operation
only and this exception must be noted on the Taxicab Operating License.
   (b)   A spare tire capable of being used on any of the wheels of the
vehicle.
   (c)   Two independently acting and entirely disconnected braking systems,
either one of which will be capable of stopping the vehicle without a load in a
distance of twenty-five feet when operating on a level, dry, asphalt street, at
the rate of twenty miles per hour.
(Ord. 10-59-2002. Passed 10-1-02.)
733.11 LICENSE SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION; TAXICAB INSPECTION.
   (a)   Whenever a taxicab is found by the Taxicab Board, at a hearing of
which the owner shall have had at least three days’ notice and at which he has
a chance to be heard, not to be in a safe and sanitary operating condition or
not to comply fully with all the requirements specified herein, the Board shall
suspend or revoke the Taxicab Operating License of the taxicab concerned.
   (b)   For the purpose of determining the condition of any taxicab, as herein
provided, the owner of such taxicab shall present it for inspection at such
time and place as may be designated by the Secretary of the Board. (Ord. 10-59-
2002. Passed 10-1-02.)
733.12 RAILROAD CROSSINGS.
   Every person operating a taxicab shall, upon approaching a railroad crossing
in the City, bring such vehicle to a complete stop before crossing such track
and shall look in both directions for approaching trains before proceeding
further.
(Ord. 10-59-2002. Passed 10-1-02.)
733.13 ESTABLISHMENT OF TAXICAB STANDS.
   The Taxicab Board shall be authorized and directed to establish and regulate
such taxicab stands as will serve the best interest of the public. Such stands
shall be reserved exclusively for the parking of taxicabs while awaiting
passengers for hire. No taxicabs shall park continuously in any parking stand
for a period exceeding one hour. It shall be the duty of the Board to designate
taxicab stands by appropriate signs indicating that they are taxicab stands.
The Board shall have continuing authority to establish, enlarge, diminish or
discontinue any taxicab stands.
(Ord. 10-59-2002. Passed 10-1-02.)
733.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever operates or permits for hire, for any consideration, a taxicab
not licensed in accordance with this chapter or employs any person as a
chauffeur or driver of a taxicab who has not been duly licensed in accordance
with this chapter, shall be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00)
nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense, and for a
second or subsequent offense, not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more
than three hundred dollars ($300.00). Any person convicted thereof shall not
thereafter be permitted to operate a taxicab within the City for a period of
one year from the date of such conviction and until this chapter has been
complied with.
   (b)   Whoever operates or permits to be operated any taxicab and violates
any provision of Sections
733.09 to
733.11 inclusive, and Section
733.13, shall be fined not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 10-59-2002. Passed 10-1-02.)
CHAPTER 737
Public Swimming Pools
737.01    Definitions.
737.02    Permit required; fees.
737.03    Permit application.
737.04    Permit issuance.
737.05    Permit revocation or suspension.   
737.06    Plans.
737.07    Design and construction of pools.
737.08    Health and safety.
737.09    Operation.
737.10    Disinfection and quality of water.
737.11    Enforcement; variances.
737.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to maintain municipal swimming pools - see Ohio R.C. 717.01(Z)
Swimming pools - see Ohio R.C. 755.12 to 755.181
Board of Recreation - see ADM. Ch.
147
737.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Public swimming pool" means any structure, basin, chamber or tank
containing a body of water for swimming, diving or recreational bathing and
having a depth of two feet or more at any point, other than a private
residential swimming pool, intended to be used collectively by a number of
persons for swimming or bathing, operated by any person, whether he is an
owner, lessee, operator, licensee or concessionaire, regardless of whether or
not a fee is charged for such use.
   (b)   "Board of Health" means the Board of Health of the Pickaway County
General Health District as created by Ohio R.C. 3709.02, or any Board of Health
established by the City or under contract for services thereto.
   (c)   "Health Commissioner" means the person occupying the office of the
Pickaway County General Health District created by Ohio R.C. 3709.11, or his
authorized representative, or the Municipal Health District, if applicable.
   (d)   "Person" means any individual, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, company, governmental agency, club or organization of any kind.
   (e)   "Operator" means the person who is responsible for operating a
swimming pool.
(Res. 23-76. Passed 3-2-76.)
737.02 PERMIT REQUIRED; FEES.
   (a)   No person shall operate or maintain a public swimming pool in the City
without a permit therefor from the Board of Health.
   (b)   All permits issued by the Board of Health to operate a public swimming
pool shall expire on April 30 following the date of issuance.
   (c)   The fee schedule shall be as follows:
      (1)   The annual permit fee for a public swimming pool, other than those
owned by a governmental agency or a school, covered by this chapter, shall be
twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
      (2)   The annual permit fee for a public swimming pool owned by a
governmental agency or a school shall be one dollar ($1.00).
(Res. 23-76. Passed 3-2-76.)
737.03 PERMIT APPLICATION.
   (a)   During the month of April of each year, every operator of a public
swimming pool proposing to operate a public swimming pool during any part of
the next twelve months shall apply for a permit therefor from the Board of
Health.
   (b)   Any person who, subsequent to May 1 of any year, proposes to operate a
public swimming pool during any remaining part of the year shall apply for a
permit therefor from the Board of Health not less than ten days before the pool
is to be opened.
(Res. 23-76. Passed 3-2-76.)
737.04 PERMIT ISSUANCE.
   (a)   On or before May 1 of each year, every operator of a public swimming
pool proposing to operate a public swimming pool during any part of the year
shall procure a permit from the Board of Health.
   (b)   Any person who, subsequent to May 1 of any year, proposes to operate a
public swimming pool during any remaining part of the year shall procure a
permit from the Board of Health before the pool is opened.
(Res. 23-76. Passed 3-2-76.)
737.05 PERMIT REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION.
   A permit to operate a public swimming pool may be suspended or revoked by
the Board of Health upon violation by the permittee of any of the provisions of
this chapter. However, such suspension or revocation shall not take place until
the permittor has first notified the permittee in writing, called specific
attention to the violation and afforded a reasonable time and opportunity for
satisfactory corrections to be made.
(Res. 23-76. Passed 3-2-76.)
737.06 PLANS.
   (a)   No person shall construct, install, provide, equip or extensively
alter a public swimming pool until the plans therefor have been submitted to
and approved in writing by the Ohio Department of Health in accordance with
Ohio R.C. 3701.18.
   (b)   A complete set of approved plans and specifications must be submitted
along with the application for a permit, on any new or extensively altered
public pool, on or after May 1 of the same year.
   (c)   The provisions of Regulations 3745-3-02 through 3745-3-05 of the Ohio
Administrative Code relating to the submission of plans and specifications for
proposed water supply, sewerage and sewage disposal plumbing, drainage and
sanitary equipment shall apply to public swimming pools.
(Res. 23-76. Passed 3-2-76.)
737.07 DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF POOLS.
   (a)   The water supply serving the public swimming pool and all plumbing
fixtures shall be adequate and of safe sanitary quality.
   (b)   The sewerage system shall be adequate to serve the facility and there
shall be no direct physical connection between the sewerage system and any
drain from the swimming pool or recirculation system.
   (c)   Swimming pools and all appurtenances thereto shall be constructed of
materials which are inert, nontoxic to man and impervious; which can withstand
the design stresses; and which will provide a tight tank with a smooth and
easily cleanable surface or to which a smooth, easily cleanable surface finish
can be applied, and which may be finished in a light color.
   (d)   The shape of any swimming pool shall be such that the circulation of
the pool water and the control of swimmers' safety are not impaired.
   (e)   The depth of the water shall be plainly marked on the edge of the deck
or walk next to the swimming pool, at maximum and minimum points, at the points
of break between the deep and shallow portions and at intermediate one-foot
increments of depth. Depth markers shall be in numerals of four inches minimum
height.
   (f)   All swimming pools shall be provided with an outlet at the deepest
point to permit the pool to be emptied. Openings must be covered by a proper
grating which is not readily removable by bathers. Inlets shall be located to
produce uniform circulation of water and to facilitate the maintenance of
uniform disinfectant residual throughout the entire swimming pool.
   (g)   Overflow gutters or skimmers shall be required on all swimming pools
to provide proper skimming and recirculation and to handle displacement water.
   (h)   A recirculation system consisting of pumps, piping, hair and lint
strainers, filters, water conditioning equipment, disinfection equipment and
other necessary equipment shall be provided which will adequately clarify and
disinfect the swimming pool water. All such equipment shall meet the approval
of the Board of Health.
   (i)   A rate-of-flow indicator or other device shall be installed and
located so that the rate of recirculation and backwash will be indicated.
   (j)   Adequate safe ladders, recessed treads, stairs and handrails shall be
provided as deemed necessary by the Board of Health.
   (k)   A continuous deck at least five feet wide shall extend completely
around the swimming pool. The deck shall be sloped away from the pool and shall
have a nonslip surface.
   (l)   Diving boards shall be so located as to provide safe clearance above
the board, adequate water depth and safe pool width at the end of the board.
   (m)   Artificial underwater lighting and artificial area lighting shall be
provided where required. All electrical wiring shall conform with applicable
local and State codes.
   (n)   All indoor swimming pools, bathhouses, dressing rooms, shower rooms
and toilet spaces shall be adequately ventilated either by natural or
mechanical means.
   (o)   Walls of bathhouses shall be of smooth finished material. Floors shall
have a nonslip surface, impervious to moisture and sloped to a drain. Junctions
between walls and floors shall be coved. Toilet and shower facilities shall
conform with the Ohio Building Code.
(Res. 23-76. Passed 3-2-76.)
737.08 HEALTH AND SAFETY.
   (a)   No person having a communicable disease shall be employed or work at a
public swimming pool. All patrons or swimmers suspected of having an infectious
disease shall be excluded.
   (b)   Appropriate facilities and personnel shall be provided for the health,
comfort and safety of bathers as may be required by the Board of Health. This
shall include lifesaving equipment, safety devices, lifebuoys, life hooks,
first-aid kits and a telephone.
(Res. 23-76. Passed 3-2-76.)
737.09 OPERATION.
   (a)   The operator of each pool shall keep a daily record of information
regarding operation and data as may be required on forms furnished by the Board
of Health. This data shall be kept on file by the operator for six months for
review of the Board.
   (b)   The pumps, filters, disinfectant and chemical feeders and related
appurtenances shall be kept in operation at all times that the swimming pool is
in use and for such additional periods as needed to keep the pool water clear
and of satisfactory bacterial quality.
(Res. 23-76. Passed 3-2-76.)
737.10 DISINFECTION AND QUALITY OF WATER.
   (a)   Swimming pools, when in use, shall be continuously disinfected with a
chemical which imparts an easily measured, free available residual effect. When
chlorine is used, a free chlorine residual of at least 0.4 p.p.m. shall be
maintained throughout the pool whenever it is open or in use. If other halogens
are used, residuals of equivalent disinfecting strength shall be maintained. A
testing kit for measuring the concentration of the disinfectant shall be
provided at each swimming pool.
   (b)   The swimming pool water shall be maintained in an alkaline condition
as indicated by a pH or not less than 7.2 and not more than 8.2. A pH testing
kit shall be provided at each swimming pool.
   (c)   The water shall have sufficient clarity at all times so that a black
disc, six inches in diameter, is readily visible when placed on a light field
at the deepest point of the swimming pool.
   (d)   No more than fifteen percent (15%) of the samples covering any
considerable period of time shall either:
      (1)   Contain more than 200 bacteria per milliliter, as determined by the
standard (thirty-five degree Centigrade) agar plate count; or
      (2)   Show a positive test (a confirmed test) for coliform organisms in
any of the five ten-milliliter portions of a sample or more than 1.0 coliform
organisms per fifty milliliters when the membrane filter test is used. The
Health Department shall arrange for the collection and examination of samples
on a routine basis when the swimming pool is in active use.
(Res. 23-76. Passed 3-2-76.)
737.11 ENFORCEMENT; VARIANCES.
   (a)   This chapter shall be enforced in accordance with Ohio R.C. 3707.48.
   (b)   The Board of Health may grant a hearing to an operator and authorize,
in specific causes, such variance from the requirements of this chapter as will
not be contrary to the public interest, where the operator shows that because
of practical difficulties or other special conditions there strict application
will cause unusual and unnecessary hardship. However, no variance shall be
granted that will defeat the spirit and general intent of this chapter or
otherwise not be in the public interest.
(Res. 23-76. Passed 3-2-76.)
737.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be punished as provided in Ohio R.C. 3707.99. Each and every
violation of or noncompliance with any of the provisions of this chapter shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Res. 23-76. Passed 3-2-76.)
CHAPTER 741
Cable Television
   EDITOR'S NOTE: This chapter grants a renewal franchise to Continental
Cablevision to operate and maintain a cable system in Circleville and sets
forth conditions.
